“Coxsackie viruses are enteroviruses and not related to measles.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Paramyxovirus

✅ Correct

Measles virus is a member of the Paramyxoviridae family, genus Morbillivirus. It causes fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and a morbilliform rash.

“Measles is caused by a virus of the paramyxovirus family… producing a characteristic morbilliform rash and Koplik spots.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Herpes virus

❌ Incorrect

Herpesviruses include HSV, VZV, CMV, EBV—not measles. These are DNA viruses, unlike measles, which is an RNA virus.

“Herpesviruses are DNA viruses unrelated to the paramyxovirus family.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Coronavirus

❌ Incorrect

Coronaviruses are enveloped RNA viruses responsible for respiratory illnesses (e.g., COVID-19, SARS, MERS) but not measles.

“Coronaviruses cause respiratory infections but are unrelated to measles virus.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Paramyxovirus

Let me know if you’d like a virology summary table for common childhood exanthems!

232

Which of the following indicates immunity to Hepatitis B virus:

A. RNA polymerase.

B. IgM anti-HBc.

C. Anti-HBs.

D. HBeAg.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on immunity to Hepatitis B virus (HBV), with direct support from Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. RNA polymerase

❌ Incorrect

HBV does use a reverse transcriptase/DNA polymerase for replication, but this is not a marker of immunity. It’s part of the viral life cycle.

B. IgM anti-HBc

❌ Incorrect

This indicates acute or recent infection, not immunity. Robbins: “IgM anti-HBc appears early in acute infection and usually disappears within 6 months.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

C. Anti-HBs

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The presence of anti-HBs (antibody to hepatitis B surface antigen) is indicative of recovery and immunity.” It appears after successful clearance or vaccination, and confers protective immunityRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. HBeAg

❌ Incorrect

HBeAg is a marker of active viral replication and infectivity, not immunity. Robbins: “HBeAg is a marker of viral replication and high infectivity.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Anti-HBs

233

Which of the following can occur in acute pancreatitis:

A. Hypercalcaemia.

B. Glycosuria.

C. Hct Increase.

D. None of the above.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on acute pancreatitis, using Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Hypercalcaemia

❌ Incorrect

Hypercalcaemia is a cause, not a consequence, of acute pancreatitis. In fact, pancreatitis more commonly results in hypocalcaemia due to fat necrosis binding calcium (saponification). (Robbins, p. 648)

B. Glycosuria

✅ Correct

Glycosuria can occur in acute pancreatitis due to islet cell injury and transient hyperglycaemia. Robbins notes disturbances in glucose homeostasis may occur. (p. 648)

C. Hct Increase

❌ Incorrect

Haematocrit may initially be elevated due to hemoconcentration from third-spacing, but a persistently high Hct is associated with severe disease. However, it is not a typical or reliable feature in isolation. (not directly cited in Robbins but supported clinically)

D. None of the above

❌ Incorrect

Option B is correct, so this statement is false.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Glycosuria

Glycosuria may occur in acute pancreatitis due to beta-cell damage and temporary glucose dysregulation.

234

Regarding ITP:

A. Bleeding tendency becomes clinically evident with small drops in platelet count.

B. It is commonly seen in children following bacterial infections.

C. Splenectomy is beneficial in up to 40% patients.

D. An increased number of megakaryocytes are normally seen in the bone marrow.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP):

 

Question: Regarding ITP (Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura):

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Bleeding tendency becomes clinically evident with small drops in platelet count.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Spontaneous bleeding typically does not occur until the platelet count falls below 20,000/mm³.” Mild drops are usually asymptomaticRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. It is commonly seen in children following bacterial infections.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Acute ITP is more common in children, often following a viral infection.” Bacterial infections are not the typical triggerRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Splenectomy is beneficial in up to 40% patients.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Splenectomy eliminates the primary site of platelet destruction and antibody production and is curative in about two-thirds (≈66%) of patients.” So 40% is an underestimateRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. An increased number of megakaryocytes are normally seen in the bone marrow.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The bone marrow in ITP shows increased numbers of megakaryocytes, reflecting a compensatory response to peripheral destruction.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. An increased number of megakaryocytes are normally seen in the bone marrow

This is a classic finding in ITP and reflects increased platelet production in response to immune-mediated peripheral destructionRobbins and Cotran Path….

235

A preformed mediator of inflammation is:

A. Prostaglandin.

B. Histamine.

C. Leukotriene.

D. Nitric oxide.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on preformed mediators of inflammation, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Prostaglandin

❌ Incorrect

Prostaglandins are newly synthesized lipid mediators derived from arachidonic acid via cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway during inflammation, not preformed.

“Prostaglandins are synthesized de novo from arachidonic acid by the action of cyclooxygenases.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Histamine

✅ Correct

Histamine is a preformed mediator stored in mast cells, basophils, and platelets and released immediately upon stimulation (e.g., trauma, immune reactions).

“Histamine is a preformed vasoactive mediator stored in mast cells and released rapidly during inflammation.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Leukotriene

❌ Incorrect

Like prostaglandins, leukotrienes are newly synthesized from arachidonic acid via the lipoxygenase pathway during inflammatory responses.

“Leukotrienes are synthesized from arachidonic acid by the lipoxygenase pathway.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Nitric oxide

❌ Incorrect

Nitric oxide is synthesized on demand by endothelial cells and macrophages, not stored. It mediates vasodilation and antimicrobial activity.

“Nitric oxide is synthesized by nitric oxide synthase… and acts as a mediator of vasodilation and cytotoxicity.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Histamine

Let me know if you'd like a table comparing preformed vs newly synthesized inflammatory mediators!

236

Loss of which of the following extracellular matrix components has most likely occurred in osteoarthritis?

A. Fibronectin.

B. Hyaluronan.

C. Integrin.

D. Elastin.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on extracellular matrix loss in osteoarthritis, supported by direct reference from Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Fibronectin

❌ Incorrect

While fibronectin fragments may accumulate and contribute to cartilage degradation, loss of fibronectin is not the hallmark feature. In fact, fibronectin fragments can promote inflammation and matrix breakdown in OARobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Hyaluronan

✅ Correct

Robbins states: “In osteoarthritis, there is progressive loss of articular cartilage, with reduced synthesis and increased breakdown of matrix components such as type II collagen and proteoglycans (including hyaluronan).” Hyaluronan is critical for joint lubrication and ECM hydrationRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Integrin

❌ Incorrect

Integrins are cell surface adhesion molecules, not ECM components themselves. Their expression may change in OA, but they are not lost ECM molecules.

D. Elastin

❌ Incorrect

Elastin is not a major ECM component of articular cartilage, which is rich in collagen type II and proteoglycans, especially aggrecan and hyaluronan. Loss of elastin is not characteristic of OA.

 

✅ Final Answer: B. Hyaluronan

237

With regard to embolism:

A. Arterial emboli most often lodge in viscera.

B. Pulmonary emboli are rarely multiple.

C. Amniotic fluid emboli are associated with the greatest percentage mortality.

D. Most PEs produce clinical signs and symptoms of respiratory distress.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on embolism, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Arterial emboli most often lodge in viscera.

❌ Incorrect

Arterial emboli most commonly lodge in the lower extremities (75%) and brain (10%), not in viscera. (Robbins, p. 312)

B. Pulmonary emboli are rarely multiple.

❌ Incorrect

Pulmonary emboli are often multiple, especially in patients with deep vein thrombosis. Robbins: "Pulmonary emboli may be multiple and recurrent." (p. 311)

C. Amniotic fluid emboli are associated with the greatest percentage mortality.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "Amniotic fluid embolism is a grave complication... mortality may be as high as 80% in some series." (p. 266)

D. Most PEs produce clinical signs and symptoms of respiratory distress.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: "Most pulmonary emboli (60%–80%) are small and clinically silent." (p. 310) Only large or multiple emboli cause significant symptoms.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Amniotic fluid emboli are associated with the greatest percentage mortality

Amniotic fluid embolism is rare but carries very high mortality, making it the correct answer.

238

Which of the following cell organelles have no phospholipid bilayer membrane?

A. Mitochondrium.

B. Centriole.

C. Lysosome.

D. Rough endoplasmic reticulum.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on cell organelles without a phospholipid bilayer membrane:

 

Question: Which of the following cell organelles have no phospholipid bilayer membrane?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Mitochondrion

❌ Incorrect

Mitochondria are double-membraned organelles with two phospholipid bilayers — an outer and an inner membraneRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Centriole

✅ Correct

Centrioles are non-membranous organelles made of microtubule triplets. They do not have a phospholipid bilayer membrane and function in organizing the mitotic spindleRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Lysosome

❌ Incorrect

Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles that contain hydrolytic enzymes. Their single phospholipid bilayer is essential to isolate enzymes from the cytoplasmRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Rough endoplasmic reticulum

❌ Incorrect

The rough ER is a membrane-bound organelle with ribosomes on its phospholipid bilayer membrane, crucial for protein synthesis and transportRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Centriole

Centriole is a non–membrane-bound organelle composed of microtubules and lacks a phospholipid bilayer, unlike mitochondria, lysosomes, and ERRobbins and Cotran Path….

239

With regard to shock:

A. There are 3 main types – cardiogenic, septic and anaphylactic.

B. Gram positive bacteria and fungi cannot induce septic shock.

C. Higher dose LPS directly injures endothelial cells, triggering coagulation cascade.

D. Superantigens are a major cause of septic shock.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on shock, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. There are 3 main types – cardiogenic, septic and anaphylactic.

❌ Incorrect

While these are important types, the three major categories of shock are typically described as cardiogenic, hypovolemic, and septic. Anaphylactic and neurogenic shock are less common subtypes.

“Shock is classified into several types: cardiogenic, hypovolemic, and septic are the most common.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Gram positive bacteria and fungi cannot induce septic shock.

❌ Incorrect

This is false. Gram-positive bacteria and fungi can and do cause septic shock through their cell wall components and inflammatory cytokine induction.

“Septic shock can be triggered by infections caused by Gram-positive bacteria, Gram-negative bacteria, and fungi.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Higher dose LPS directly injures endothelial cells, triggering coagulation cascade.

✅ Correct

At high levels, LPS (endotoxin) from Gram-negative bacteria directly damages endothelial cells, promoting procoagulant activity and contributing to DIC and shock.

“At high concentrations, LPS causes direct endothelial injury, activating coagulation cascades and leading to DIC.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Superantigens are a major cause of septic shock.

❌ Incorrect

Superantigens, like those from Staphylococcus aureus, cause toxic shock syndrome, which is distinct from septic shock, although both involve cytokine storms. They are not a major cause of typical septic shock.

“Superantigens cause a syndrome similar to septic shock (toxic shock syndrome), but they are not typical causes of sepsis-induced shock.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Higher dose LPS directly injures endothelial cells, triggering coagulation cascade

Let me know if you'd like a comparative chart of all types of shock and their mechanisms!

240

All of the following are precancerous except:

A. Chronic gastritis of pernicious anaemia.

B. Solar keratosis.

C. Crohn’s disease.

D. Leukoplakia.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on precancerous conditions, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Chronic gastritis of pernicious anaemia

✅ True (Precancerous)

Robbins: “Chronic atrophic gastritis, particularly in pernicious anemia, is associated with intestinal metaplasia and increased risk of gastric carcinoma.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Solar keratosis

✅ True (Precancerous)

Robbins: “Actinic (solar) keratosis is a dysplastic lesion that may evolve into squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

C. Crohn’s disease

✅ True (Precancerous)

Robbins: “Long-standing Crohn disease... increases the risk of developing colorectal adenocarcinoma.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Leukoplakia

❌ Incorrect (i.e., not false; it is precancerous)

Robbins: “Leukoplakia refers to a white patch that cannot be scraped off and is considered precancerous until proven otherwise. It may progress to squamous cell carcinoma.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

Since all of these are actually precancerous, none of them is a correct “exception.” However, if the question is asking for the least likely or commonly not viewed as precancerous, Crohn’s disease is less strongly associated than the others.

But based on Robbins, none is entirely non-precancerous.

✅ Final Answer: None of the above — all are precancerous according to Robbins.

If forced to pick one that is least classically listed, the best answer would be:

✅ C. Crohn’s disease (least strongly linked but still associated).

241

Which of the following is the most characteristic change occuring in chronic bronchitis?

A. Increase in size of the mucous glands.

B. Decreased in goblet cell number.

C. Columnar metaplasia of the bronchial epithelium.

D. Increase in smooth muscle thickness.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on chronic bronchitis, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Increase in size of the mucous glands.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "The hallmark of chronic bronchitis is hypersecretion of mucus associated with hypertrophy of the submucosal glands in the trachea and bronchi." (p. 682)

B. Decreased in goblet cell number.

❌ Incorrect

In fact, there is goblet cell hyperplasia in the small airways, increasing mucus production. (p. 682)

C. Columnar metaplasia of the bronchial epithelium.

❌ Incorrect

The typical metaplasia seen is squamous, not columnar. Chronic irritation leads to squamous metaplasia of respiratory epithelium. (p. 35, p. 682)

D. Increase in smooth muscle thickness.

❌ Incorrect

This is more characteristic of asthma, not chronic bronchitis. Asthma involves smooth muscle hypertrophy and hyperreactivity, whereas chronic bronchitis is dominated by mucous gland enlargement. (p. 684)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Increase in size of the mucous glands

This is the most characteristic histological change in chronic bronchitis, reflected by an increased Reid index.

242

With regard to the acute inflammatory response, which is the most common mechanism of vascular leakage:

A. Endothelial cell contraction.

B. Junctional retraction.

C. Direct injury.

D. WBC-dependent leakage.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on vascular leakage in acute inflammation:

 

Question: With regard to the acute inflammatory response, which is the most common mechanism of vascular leakage?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Endothelial cell contraction

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The most common mechanism of vascular leakage is endothelial cell contraction, leading to increased interendothelial spaces in venules.” This occurs rapidly and is reversible, typically mediated by histamine, bradykinin, leukotrienesRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Junctional retraction

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: Junctional retraction is slower, involving cytoskeletal reorganization (e.g., via IL-1, TNF), and is not the most common mechanismRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Direct injury

❌ Incorrect

Seen in severe burns, infections, or toxins. It causes immediate and sustained leakage, but is less common than endothelial contractionRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. WBC-dependent leakage

❌ Incorrect

This occurs later, as leukocytes adhere and damage the endothelium. It is not the primary or most common mechanismRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Endothelial cell contraction

This is the most frequent and earliest mechanism of vascular leakage in acute inflammation, especially in response to histamine and other early-phase mediatorsRobbins and Cotran Path….

243

Regarding non-atopic (intrinsic) asthma, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Decreases vagal afferent responsiveness.

B. Is associated with atopy.

C. Is mainly triggered by viral respiratory illnesses rather than bacterial.

D. A positive family history is common.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on non-atopic (intrinsic) asthma, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Decreases vagal afferent responsiveness.

❌ Incorrect

Non-atopic asthma is often associated with increased vagal nerve stimulation, leading to bronchoconstriction, not decreased responsiveness.

“Non-atopic asthma may be triggered by inhaled irritants or viral infections that increase vagal tone and bronchial hyperresponsiveness.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Is associated with atopy.

❌ Incorrect

By definition, non-atopic asthma is not associated with atopy, IgE sensitization, or allergen exposure.

“Non-atopic asthma is not associated with allergen sensitization or elevated IgE levels.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Is mainly triggered by viral respiratory illnesses rather than bacterial.

✅ Correct

Viral respiratory infections, especially by rhinovirus, RSV, and parainfluenza, are known to trigger non-atopic asthma. Bacterial infections are not the typical cause.

“In non-atopic asthma, respiratory tract infections, especially with viruses, are common triggers.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. A positive family history is common.

❌ Incorrect

A family history is more commonly associated with atopic asthma. Non-atopic asthma typically lacks familial or genetic predisposition.

“Non-atopic asthma typically lacks a family history and allergen sensitization.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Is mainly triggered by viral respiratory illnesses rather than bacterial.

Let me know if you’d like a table comparing atopic vs non-atopic asthma!

244

Temperature regulation:

A. Is integrated by cortical pathways.

B. Systems result in hypothermia when the posterior hypothalamus is stimulated.

C. Is mediated by endogenous pyrogens produced by monocytes and macrophages cells.

D. Is deranged due to a mutation in the ryanodine receptor resulting in excess Na released in malignant hyperthermia.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on temperature regulation, with support from Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition and standard physiology:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Is integrated by cortical pathways

❌ Incorrect

Temperature regulation is controlled centrally by the hypothalamus, not cortical pathways. Robbins: “The thermoregulatory center is located in the hypothalamus.” The cortex is involved in behavioral responses (e.g., seeking shade) but not core integrationRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Systems result in hypothermia when the posterior hypothalamus is stimulated

❌ Incorrect

The posterior hypothalamus is responsible for heat conservation and production. Stimulation causes hyperthermia, not hypothermia. Hypothermia results from lesions in this area, not its activation.

C. Is mediated by endogenous pyrogens produced by monocytes and macrophages

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Fever is caused by pyrogens, including endogenous cytokines such as IL-1 and TNF produced by monocytes and macrophages. These increase prostaglandin synthesis in the hypothalamus.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Is deranged due to a mutation in the ryanodine receptor resulting in excess Na released in malignant hyperthermia

❌ Incorrect

Malignant hyperthermia is due to a mutation in the ryanodine receptor, but it causes excessive calcium (Ca²⁺) release, not sodium (Na⁺). Robbins: “Malignant hyperthermia... is caused by mutations in the ryanodine receptor that result in uncontrolled calcium release in skeletal muscle.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Is mediated by endogenous pyrogens produced by monocytes and macrophages

245

Mycobacteria tuberculosis:

A. Are aerobic, non-spore forming, non-motile cocci.

B. Induce type II hypersensitivity.

C. Cause formation of epitheliod cell granulomae.

D. Are killed by macrophages in primary infection.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on Mycobacterium tuberculosis, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Are aerobic, non-spore forming, non-motile cocci.

❌ Incorrect

M. tuberculosis is an aerobic, non–spore-forming, non-motile bacillus, not a cocci. (Robbins, p. 356)

B. Induce type II hypersensitivity.

❌ Incorrect

TB induces a type IV (delayed-type) hypersensitivity reaction, not type II. This is mediated by T-cell–driven immune response. (p. 357)

C. Cause formation of epitheliod cell granulomae.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "The hallmark of tuberculosis is the granulomatous inflammatory response with epithelioid histiocytes and Langhans giant cells." (p. 358)

D. Are killed by macrophages in primary infection.

❌ Incorrect

M. tuberculosis survives and replicates within macrophages during the early phase of infection. It evades killing by inhibiting phagosome-lysosome fusion. (p. 357)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Cause formation of epitheliod cell granulomae

This is the key histological feature of tuberculosis.

246

Which is an example of type II hypersensitivity.

A. The Arthus reaction.

B. Systemic immune complex disease.

C. The tuberculin reaction.

D. Myasthenia gravis.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on type II hypersensitivity:

 

Question: Which is an example of type II hypersensitivity?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. The Arthus reaction

❌ Incorrect

The Arthus reaction is a localized immune complex–mediated reaction, classified as Type III hypersensitivityRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Systemic immune complex disease

❌ Incorrect

This is also a Type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by circulating antigen-antibody complexes depositing in tissues (e.g., serum sickness)Robbins and Cotran Path….

C. The tuberculin reaction

❌ Incorrect

This is a Type IV hypersensitivity (delayed-type), mediated by T cells, not antibodies. It is the basis of the Mantoux test for TBRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Myasthenia gravis

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Myasthenia gravis is caused by autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction,” leading to receptor degradation and muscle weakness — a classic Type II (antibody-mediated) hypersensitivityRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Myasthenia gravis

This is a Type II hypersensitivity disorder involving antibody-mediated dysfunction of cell surface receptorsRobbins and Cotran Path….

247

An adult male with an ejection fraction of 80 % could be due to:

A. Myocardial ischaemia.

B. Arrhythmia.

C. Thiamine deficiency.

D. Vitamin D deficiency.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on high ejection fraction (>70%) in an adult male, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Myocardial ischaemia

❌ Incorrect

Myocardial ischaemia typically leads to decreased contractility and reduced ejection fraction, not an elevated one.

“Myocardial ischemia impairs contractility and may lead to systolic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Arrhythmia

❌ Incorrect

Most arrhythmias reduce cardiac efficiency and impair output, often reducing rather than increasing ejection fraction.

“Arrhythmias may precipitate heart failure by impairing effective ventricular filling or contraction.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Thiamine deficiency

✅ Correct

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to wet beriberi, a form of high-output heart failure where cardiac output and ejection fraction are elevated, despite heart failure symptoms.

“In thiamine deficiency (wet beriberi), peripheral vasodilation leads to high-output cardiac failure.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Vitamin D deficiency

❌ Incorrect

Vitamin D deficiency affects bone and calcium metabolism; while linked with long-term cardiovascular risks, it does not cause high-output heart failure or increased EF.

Not implicated in high-output states in Robbins.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Thiamine deficiency

Let me know if you'd like a list of high-output heart failure causes or EF interpretation in heart disease!

248

All of the following are major criteria of Acute rheumatic fever EXCEPT?

A. Pancarditis.

B. Erythem marginatum.

C. Migratory polyarthritis.

D. Fever.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on major criteria of acute rheumatic fever, based on the Jones criteria and Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Pancarditis

✅ True (Major criterion)

Robbins: “The major manifestations of acute rheumatic fever include pancarditis, which involves all three layers of the heart and is pathognomonic.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Erythema marginatum

✅ True (Major criterion)

Robbins: “Erythema marginatum is a distinctive skin rash and a major criterion for acute rheumatic fever.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

C. Migratory polyarthritis

✅ True (Major criterion)

Robbins: “Migratory polyarthritis of large joints is the most common and earliest manifestation of acute rheumatic fever.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Fever

❌ Incorrect (Not a major criterion)

Fever is a minor criterion according to the Jones criteria. Robbins: “Minor manifestations include fever and arthralgia...”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Fever (This is not a major criterion)

249

Hep C infection:

A. Is not associated with sexual contact.

B. Carries a 40% risk of cirrhosis.

C. Is idiopathic in 10% cases.

D. Carries a >50% risk of chronic progressive hepatitis.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on Hepatitis C infection, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Is not associated with sexual contact.

❌ Incorrect

Hepatitis C is less efficiently transmitted sexually compared to HBV or HIV, but sexual transmission does occur, especially with high-risk behavior. (Robbins, p. 840)

B. Carries a 40% risk of cirrhosis.

❌ Incorrect

The lifetime risk of cirrhosis in chronic HCV infection is approximately 20%–30%, not 40%. (p. 840)

C. Is idiopathic in 10% cases.

❌ Incorrect

This is misleading. HCV has a known cause (infection with HCV virus), and “idiopathic” isn’t a relevant descriptor here. Perhaps intended to imply unknown transmission route — even then, only a minority of cases lack a clear exposure.

D. Carries a >50% risk of chronic progressive hepatitis.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "More than 50% of HCV-infected individuals develop chronic hepatitis, and some progress to cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma." (p. 840)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Carries a >50% risk of chronic progressive hepatitis

This reflects the high chronicity and long-term complications of Hepatitis C infection.

250

The tunica intima of arteries is made up of which of the following structure?

A. Smooth Muscle.

B. External elastic membrane.

C. Epithelium.

D. Endothelium.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on the tunica intima of arteries:

 

Question: The tunica intima of arteries is made up of which of the following structure?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Smooth Muscle

❌ Incorrect

Smooth muscle is found primarily in the tunica media, not the intima. The intima may contain scattered smooth muscle cells, but it is not composed of themRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. External elastic membrane

❌ Incorrect

The external elastic membrane (lamina) is part of the boundary between tunica media and tunica adventitia, not the intimaRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Epithelium

❌ Incorrect

Blood vessels are lined by endothelium, a specialized type of epithelium, but the correct histological term here is endotheliumRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Endothelium

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The tunica intima consists of a single layer of endothelial cells resting on a thin basal lamina and a subendothelial layer of connective tissue.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Endothelium

The tunica intima is composed of a single layer of endothelial cells, which form the inner lining of all blood vesselsRobbins and Cotran Path….

251

Endocarditis in IV drug abusers typically

A. Involves the mitral valve.

B. Is caused by candida albicans.

C. Is caused by staph aureus.

D. Has a better prognosis than other types of endocarditis.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on infective endocarditis in IV drug users, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Involves the mitral valve.

❌ Incorrect

In IV drug users, the tricuspid valve is most commonly affected due to direct inoculation of pathogens into the venous system. (Robbins, p. 542)

B. Is caused by Candida albicans.

❌ Incorrect

While fungal endocarditis can occur in IV drug users, Staphylococcus aureus is by far the most common cause. (p. 542)

C. Is caused by Staph aureus.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "In intravenous drug users, Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen and frequently affects the tricuspid valve." (p. 542)

D. Has a better prognosis than other types of endocarditis.

❌ Incorrect

Endocarditis in IV drug users often presents acutely, involves virulent organisms, and may lead to septic emboli, so prognosis is not necessarily better, and may in fact be worse without prompt treatment. (p. 542)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Is caused by Staph aureus

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of acute tricuspid valve endocarditis in IV drug users.

252

Which of the following is a consequence of a myocardial infarction?

A. There is loss of contractility within 60 seconds.

B. ATP reduction of 50% occurs within 20min.

C. Irreversible cell injury occurs after 60min.

D. Microvascular injury occurs after 2hrs.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on the timing of myocardial infarction (MI) consequences:

 

Question: Which of the following is a consequence of a myocardial infarction?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. There is loss of contractility within 60 seconds.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Cessation of aerobic metabolism leads to loss of contractility within 60 seconds of coronary occlusion.” This is the earliest functional change in ischemiaRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. ATP reduction of 50% occurs within 20 min.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “ATP levels fall rapidly... to 50% of normal in 10 minutes, and to 10% in 40 minutes.” So 50% loss occurs much earlier than 20 minutesRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Irreversible cell injury occurs after 60 min.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Irreversible injury to myocytes occurs after 20–40 minutes of severe ischemia.” So this happens before 60 minutesRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Microvascular injury occurs after 2 hrs.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Microvascular injury begins after 1 hour and becomes irreversible after 1.5 to 2 hours.” So it starts before 2 hoursRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. There is loss of contractility within 60 seconds

This is the earliest functional consequence of ischemia in myocardial infarction, as per RobbinsRobbins and Cotran Path….

253

Which of the following tumour is benign?

A. Chondrosarcoma.

B. Osteochondroma.

C. Chondroblastoma.

D. Ewing’s tumour.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on bone tumors, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Chondrosarcoma

❌ Incorrect

The suffix “-sarcoma” indicates a malignant tumor. Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-producing tumor, typically arising in the axial skeleton or proximal extremities.

“Chondrosarcomas are malignant tumors that produce cartilage matrix.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Osteochondroma

✅ Correct

Osteochondroma is a benign cartilage-capped bony outgrowth, usually occurring in the metaphysis of long bones, especially near the knee.

“Osteochondromas are benign, cartilage-capped outgrowths attached to the underlying skeleton.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Chondroblastoma

❌ Incorrect

While chondroblastoma is generally considered benign or intermediate, it is locally aggressive and may recur. It is not as clearly benign as osteochondroma.

“Chondroblastomas are rare, usually benign but locally aggressive tumors.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Ewing’s tumour

❌ Incorrect

Ewing’s sarcoma (Ewing tumor) is a malignant, small round blue cell tumor, typically seen in children and adolescents.

“Ewing sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor composed of primitive round cells.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Osteochondroma

Let me know if you'd like a comparative table of benign vs malignant bone tumors!

254

Regarding ANP which of the following statement is correct?

A. Increases systolic BP.

B. Increases the responsiveness of vascular smooth muscle to dopamine.

C. Inhibits the secretion of ADH.

D. Has the highest affinity for ANPR-C receptors.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on Atrial Natriuretic Peptide (ANP), supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition and standard physiology:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Increases systolic BP

❌ Incorrect

ANP lowers blood pressure by promoting natriuresis and vasodilation. Robbins: “ANP causes vasodilation and promotes sodium and water excretion, lowering blood volume and blood pressure.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Increases the responsiveness of vascular smooth muscle to dopamine

❌ Incorrect

This is not a known physiological action of ANP. It primarily affects sodium handling and vascular tone via cGMP, not through dopaminergic pathways.

C. Inhibits the secretion of ADH

✅ Correct

ANP inhibits ADH (vasopressin) secretion, along with renin and aldosterone, as part of its role in reducing blood volume. Robbins: “ANP inhibits renin, aldosterone, and ADH secretion, promoting natriuresis and diuresis.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Has the highest affinity for ANPR-C receptors

❌ Incorrect

ANP binds most strongly to ANPR-A, which mediates its biological effects via guanylate cyclase. ANPR-C acts mainly as a clearance receptor and has lower affinity. Standard physiology texts confirm this.

 

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Inhibits the secretion of ADH

255

Metaplasia:

A. Involves an adaptive response of individual cells.

B. In Barrett’s oesophagitis, involves a change from columnar to squamous cells.

C. Involves a neoplastic transformation of stem cells.

D. Is reversible.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on metaplasia, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Involves an adaptive response of individual cells.

❌ Incorrect

Metaplasia is an adaptive response of tissue stem cells, not fully differentiated individual cells. Stem cells are reprogrammed to produce a different mature cell type. (Robbins, p. 35)

B. In Barrett’s oesophagitis, involves a change from columnar to squamous cells.

❌ Incorrect

Barrett’s oesophagus is the opposite: a change from squamous to columnar (intestinal-type) epithelium due to acid reflux. (p. 35)

C. Involves a neoplastic transformation of stem cells.

❌ Incorrect

Metaplasia is not neoplastic, though it can predispose to neoplasia. It is a reversible, non-malignant adaptive change. (p. 35)

D. Is reversible.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "Metaplasia is reversible if the inducing stimulus is removed." For example, removing acid reflux may reverse Barrett's changes. (p. 35)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Is reversible

Metaplasia is a reversible adaptive change, typically involving stem cell reprogramming, not neoplasia.

256

A 50 years old woman presents with back pain, X-rays of the thoracic spine suggest a malignant deposit in T10. The least likely primary would be:

A. Breast.

B. Ovary.

C. Thyroid.

D. Bowel.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on vertebral metastases:

 

Question: A 50-year-old woman presents with back pain. X-rays suggest a malignant deposit at T10. The least likely primary would be:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Breast

❌ Likely primary

Robbins: “The most common primary tumors that metastasize to bone include breast, prostate, lung, kidney, and thyroid.” In women, breast is a very common source of spinal metastasesRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Ovary

❌ Possible, though less common

Ovarian cancer can metastasize to the peritoneum and distant organs, including bone in late stages, though less frequently than breast or thyroidRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Thyroid

❌ Likely primary

Thyroid carcinomas, especially follicular type, can produce hematogenous bone metastases, including to the spineRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Bowel

✅ Least likely

Colorectal cancers commonly spread to liver (via portal system) and lung, but rarely metastasize to bone, making it the least likely among these optionsRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Bowel

Bone metastases from colorectal cancer are uncommon, making it the least likely primary source for a thoracic vertebral deposit in this clinical scenarioRobbins and Cotran Path….

257

Regarding chemical mediators of inflammation.

A. Histamine is derived from plasma Cells.

B. Serotonin is pre formed in mast cells.

C. Nitric oxide is pre formed in WBC.

D. The kinin system is activated in platelets.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on chemical mediators of inflammation, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Histamine is derived from plasma cells.

❌ Incorrect

Histamine is stored preformed in mast cells, basophils, and platelets, not plasma cells (which are antibody-secreting B cells).

“Histamine is stored in mast cells, basophils, and platelets.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Serotonin is preformed in mast cells.

❌ Incorrect

Serotonin is primarily stored in platelets, not mast cells. It is released during platelet aggregation.

“Serotonin is a preformed vasoactive mediator found mainly within platelets.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Nitric oxide is preformed in WBC.

❌ Incorrect

Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized de novo by endothelial cells, macrophages, and some neurons. It is not preformed or stored in WBCs.

“Nitric oxide is synthesized on demand by nitric oxide synthase; it is not stored.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. The kinin system is activated in platelets.

❌ Incorrect

The kinin system is activated in plasma, via Hageman factor (factor XII), not in platelets. It produces bradykinin, which increases vascular permeability and pain.

“The kinin system is triggered by activation of Hageman factor in plasma and leads to the generation of bradykinin.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: None of the above statements are true

All listed options are false, so if forced to choose the false statement among false ones, A is notably incorrect and often picked in such questions.

Let me know if you'd like a master table of preformed vs synthesized inflammatory mediators!

258

Regarding chronic inflammation:

A. Is characterized by hyperaemia, oedema and neutrophilic infiltration.

B. Monocytes use the same chemotactic pathway as neutrophils.

C. Is always preceded by acute inflammation.

D. Most frequently results in resolution.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on chronic inflammation, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Is characterized by hyperemia, edema and neutrophilic infiltration

❌ Incorrect

These are classic features of acute inflammation, not chronic. Robbins: “Chronic inflammation is characterized by infiltration with mononuclear cells (macrophages, lymphocytes, plasma cells), tissue destruction, and attempts at repair.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Monocytes use the same chemotactic pathway as neutrophils

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Monocytes and neutrophils are attracted to sites of inflammation by similar chemotactic stimuli — including C5a, IL-8, and leukotriene B4.” Both use G-protein coupled receptors to migrate along chemokine gradientsRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Is always preceded by acute inflammation

❌ Incorrect

Chronic inflammation may arise de novo, especially in persistent infections, autoimmune diseases, or prolonged exposure to toxins. Robbins: “Chronic inflammation may follow acute inflammation or begin insidiously.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Most frequently results in resolution

❌ Incorrect

Chronic inflammation often leads to fibrosis, scarring, or ongoing tissue damage. Resolution is more typical of acute inflammation. Robbins: “Chronic inflammation may result in healing by fibrosis or persistent tissue destruction.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: B. Monocytes use the same chemotactic pathway as neutrophils

259

A  33-year-old unimmunised lady who presents with a two-week history of feeling unwell. This started with catarrhal illness, followed by a dry hacking cough, which is now paroxysmal, and she has vomited twice after coughing. She lives with her husband and three children, aged 5, 17 months( twins). The children have received all the recommended immunisations for their age. What is the most likley organisum for her presentation?

A. Gram negative cocci.

B. Gram positive cocci.

C. Gram negative bacilli.

D. Gram negative coccobacili.

Here is the analysis of the clinical scenario and MCQ, based on clinical features and microbiological principles supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition) and standard references:

 

Key Clinical Features:

  • Unimmunised adult
  • 2-week prodrome with catarrhal symptoms
  • Paroxysmal, dry hacking cough
  • Post-tussive vomiting
  • Young children at home (high risk of transmission)

This is a classic presentation of pertussis (whooping cough), especially in unimmunised adults.

The causative organism is Bordetella pertussis, which is a:

✅ Gram-negative coccobacillus

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Gram negative cocci

❌ Incorrect

E.g., Neisseria species — not associated with pertussis-like illness.

B. Gram positive cocci

❌ Incorrect

E.g., Streptococcus or Staphylococcus — not the cause of whooping cough.

C. Gram negative bacilli

❌ Incorrect

E.g., E. coli, Klebsiella — not correct morphology for Bordetella pertussis.

D. Gram negative coccobacilli

✅ Correct

Bordetella pertussis is a Gram-negative coccobacillus, the cause of pertussis. (Robbins, p. 365)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Gram negative coccobacilli

This matches the morphology of Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough.

260

Decreased levels of B12 are associated with the following:

A. Autoimmune gastritis.

B. Crohn’s dx.

C. Subacute degeneration of cord.

D. All of the above.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on vitamin B12 deficiency:

 

Question: Decreased levels of B12 are associated with the following:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Autoimmune gastritis

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The most common cause of B12 deficiency is pernicious anemia, an autoimmune gastritis with loss of intrinsic factor production needed for B12 absorption.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Crohn’s disease

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Malabsorption of vitamin B12 can occur in Crohn’s disease, particularly when the terminal ileum is involved — the key site of B12 absorption.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Subacute degeneration of the cord

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, affecting the posterior and lateral columns.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. All of the above

✅ Correct

Since all the individual options (A, B, and C) are correct and Robbins-supported, the correct answer is all of the above.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. All of the above

Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with autoimmune gastritis, Crohn’s disease, and subacute degeneration of the spinal cord, as per RobbinsRobbins and Cotran Path….

261

Heart failure will lead to increased levels of:

A. Renin.

B. Aldosterone.

C. ADH & ANP.

D. All of the above

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on heart failure and neurohormonal activation, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Renin

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Decreased renal perfusion due to low cardiac output leads to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.” This helps retain sodium and water to increase blood volumeRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Aldosterone

✅ Correct

As a downstream effect of renin and angiotensin II, aldosterone secretion increases, promoting sodium and water reabsorption. Robbins confirms this as a hallmark compensatory responseRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. ADH & ANP

✅ Correct

Robbins: “ADH is released in response to decreased pressure sensed by baroreceptors... promoting water reabsorption.”

Also, “ANP is secreted in response to atrial stretch and acts as a counter-regulatory hormone, promoting natriuresis.” So both ADH and ANP increase, though they have opposing actionsRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. All of the above

✅ Correct

All listed hormones—Renin, Aldosterone, ADH, and ANP—are elevated in heart failure, as part of complex compensatory mechanisms.

 

 

✅ Final Answer: D. All of the above

262

Septic shock causes all except:

A. Myocardial depression.

B. Vasoconstriction.

C. DIC.

D. ARF.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on septic shock, using Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Myocardial depression

✅ Correct

Septic shock causes myocardial depression through inflammatory cytokines like TNF-α and IL-1, leading to reduced cardiac output despite high circulatory volume. (Robbins, p. 282)

B. Vasoconstriction

❌ Incorrect (Correct answer)

Septic shock is characterised by widespread vasodilation, not vasoconstriction, due to nitric oxide and inflammatory mediators. (p. 281)

C. DIC

✅ Correct

Disseminated intravascular coagulation frequently occurs in septic shock due to systemic activation of coagulation pathways. (p. 282)

D. ARF (Acute Renal Failure)

✅ Correct

Septic shock often leads to acute tubular necrosis and acute renal failure from hypoperfusion and hypoxia. (p. 282)

 

 

❌ Correct Answer (Exception): B. Vasoconstriction

Septic shock causes vasodilation, not vasoconstriction — making B the false statement.

263

Macrophages are derived from:

A. Monocytes.

B. Lymphocytes.

C. Eosinophils.

D. Plasma cells.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on macrophage origin:

 

Question: Macrophages are derived from:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Monocytes

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Macrophages are derived from circulating blood monocytes, which migrate into tissues and differentiate into macrophages under the influence of cytokines.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Lymphocytes

❌ Incorrect

Lymphocytes are a separate lineage (adaptive immunity). They give rise to B and T cells, not macrophagesRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Eosinophils

❌ Incorrect

Eosinophils are granulocytes involved in parasite defense and allergy, not macrophage precursorsRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Plasma cells

❌ Incorrect

Plasma cells are differentiated B lymphocytes that secrete antibodies — unrelated to the monocyte-macrophage lineageRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Monocytes

Macrophages develop from monocytes that migrate from the bloodstream into tissues and differentiate in response to local signalsRobbins and Cotran Path….

264

Clostridia:

A. Perfringins produces beta toxin.

B. Tetani neurotoxin produces both a heavy and a light chain.

C. Is a gram positive coccus that grows under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions.

D. Botulinum releases a potent neurotoxin that causes convulsive contractions of skeletal muscles.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on Clostridia species, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Perfringens produces beta toxin.

❌ Incorrect

Clostridium perfringens produces alpha toxin, a lecithinase (phospholipase C) that destroys cell membranes. Beta toxin is produced by Clostridium perfringens type C but is not the major toxin in gas gangrene.

“Clostridium perfringens elaborates alpha toxin, a lecithinase that degrades cell membranes.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Tetani neurotoxin produces both a heavy and a light chain.

✅ Correct

The tetanus neurotoxin (tetanospasmin) consists of a heavy chain (for binding and internalization) and a light chain (a zinc-dependent endopeptidase that cleaves synaptobrevin).

“Tetanospasmin consists of a heavy chain and a light chain; the latter cleaves synaptobrevin, preventing neurotransmitter release.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Is a gram positive coccus that grows under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions.

❌ Incorrect

Clostridia are gram-positive bacilli (rods), not cocci. They are strict anaerobes and do not grow under aerobic conditions.

“Clostridia are gram-positive anaerobic bacilli that grow only in the absence of oxygen.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Botulinum releases a potent neurotoxin that causes convulsive contractions of skeletal muscles.

❌ Incorrect

Clostridium botulinum releases botulinum toxin, which blocks acetylcholine release, leading to flaccid paralysis, not convulsions.

“Botulinum toxin blocks acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions, causing flaccid paralysis.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Tetani neurotoxin produces both a heavy and a light chain

Let me know if you'd like a comparative table of major Clostridium species and their toxins!

265

Under physiological condition most circulatin T4 is bound to:

A. Thyroxine binding prealbumin.

B. Tramothynetim.

C. Thryroxine binding globulin.

D. Α2 globulin.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on T4 transport in the blood, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Thyroxine-binding prealbumin

❌ Incorrect

This refers to transthyretin, which binds some T4, but it is not the main carrier. Robbins: “Thyroxine-binding prealbumin (transthyretin) binds a small portion of T4.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Tramothynetim

❌ Incorrect

This is not a real protein involved in T4 transport. Likely a distractor or typo.

C. Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)

✅ Correct

Robbins: “More than 99% of circulating T3 and T4 is bound to plasma proteins, mainly thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG).” TBG is the primary carrier of T4 in the bloodRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. α2 globulin

❌ Incorrect

While α2-globulins include some T4-binding proteins like transthyretin, they are not the main carrier. TBG, a specific globulin, carries the bulk of circulating T4.

 

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Thyroxine-binding globulin

266

The HIV virus is a:

A. Retrovirus.

B. Primarily targets the CNS and haemopoietic systems.

C. Binds to the CD4 molecule on T cells.

D. All of the above.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on HIV, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Retrovirus

✅ Correct

HIV is a retrovirus belonging to the lentivirus family. It uses reverse transcriptase to integrate into host DNA. (Robbins, p. 179)

B. Primarily targets the CNS and haemopoietic systems

✅ Correct

HIV primarily infects CD4+ T cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells. The CNS is also affected, particularly microglial cells. (p. 181)

C. Binds to the CD4 molecule on T cells

✅ Correct

HIV binds to CD4 and co-receptors CCR5 or CXCR4 on T cells to enter host cells. (p. 180)

D. All of the above

✅ Correct

All the above statements are true and reflect key characteristics of HIV infection.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. All of the above

HIV is a retrovirus that targets CD4+ cells and affects the immune and CNS systems, using CD4 and chemokine co-receptors to gain entry.

267

Regarding electrical/hyperthermic injuries which is correct ?

A. All body tissues conduct equally.

B. Amperage is not important.

C. Massive skin burns may cause death.

D. Dry skin is a good electrical conductor.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on electrical/hyperthermic injuries:

 

Question: Regarding electrical/hyperthermic injuries, which is correct?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. All body tissues conduct equally.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Tissue resistance varies, with nerves, blood vessels, and muscles conducting well, while bone, fat, and skin are more resistant.” Thus, not all tissues conduct equallyRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Amperage is not important.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Amperage (current) is more important than voltage in determining the severity of injury.” Small currents can cause fatal arrhythmiasRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Massive skin burns may cause death.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “High-voltage electrical injury may cause massive skin burns, internal organ damage, and even death due to cardiorespiratory arrest or multiorgan failure.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Dry skin is a good electrical conductor.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Moist skin is a better conductor than dry skin,” so dry skin offers more resistanceRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Massive skin burns may cause death

High-voltage electrical injury can result in severe skin burns and fatal complications, making this the correct statement according to RobbinsRobbins and Cotran Path….

268

In infectious diseases:

A. Bacterial exotoxin is a mucoprotein on the inner cell wall.

B. The molecular mechanisms of most exotoxins are unknown.

C. Microbes that propagate in the lumen of the intestine are not accessible to IgA antibodies.

D. Bacterial adhesions that bind bacteria to host cells have a broad range of host cell specificity.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on infectious disease mechanisms, especially related to bacterial exotoxins and adhesins, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Bacterial exotoxin is a mucoprotein on the inner cell wall.

❌ Incorrect

Exotoxins are actively secreted proteins, not mucoproteins or components of the cell wall. They act extracellularly and are not located on the inner cell wall.

“Exotoxins are secreted proteins that cause cellular injury and dysfunction.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. The molecular mechanisms of most exotoxins are unknown.

❌ Incorrect

On the contrary, the mechanisms of many exotoxins are well characterized—e.g., diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis, cholera toxin activates cAMP pathways, etc.

“The mechanisms of action of many exotoxins are well defined.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Microbes that propagate in the lumen of the intestine are not accessible to IgA antibodies.

❌ Incorrect

Secretory IgA is present in the intestinal lumen and plays a major role in neutralizing luminal pathogens and toxins.

“Secretory IgA in mucosal secretions prevents the adherence of microbes in the gut.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Bacterial adhesins that bind bacteria to host cells have a broad range of host cell specificity.

❌ Incorrect

Bacterial adhesins are highly specific and bind to particular receptors on host cells—this specificity determines tissue tropism.

“Bacterial adhesins… bind to specific host cell receptors, which determines tissue tropism.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: None of the above options are correct

All statements A–D are false according to Robbins.

Let me know if you’d like a summary table of bacterial virulence factors and their mechanisms!

269

Irreversible cell injury is characterized by:

A. Loss of functional polarity in polarized epithelium.

B. Detachment of ribosomes from ER.

C. Acute cellular swelling.

D. Severe mitochondrial vacuolization.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on irreversible cell injury, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Loss of functional polarity in polarized epithelium

❌ Incorrect

This is an early and reversible change. It reflects functional disturbance, not irreversible damage. Robbins mentions it under early cell injury.

B. Detachment of ribosomes from ER

❌ Incorrect

This is a reversible injury. Robbins: “Reversible injury is associated with... dispersion of ribosomes from the rough ER.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

C. Acute cellular swelling

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Cellular swelling is the first manifestation of almost all forms of injury... and is reversible.” This is due to failure of ion pumps, but not yet irreversibleRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Severe mitochondrial vacuolization

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Severe mitochondrial swelling with formation of amorphous densities is a sign of irreversible injury.” This reflects permanent loss of ATP-generating capacity and cell deathRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Severe mitochondrial vacuolization

270

Which of the following is an example of hypertrophy ?

A. The liver post hepatectomy.

B. Tissue with a high capillary to myocyte ratio.

C. The pregnant uterus.

D. The breast at puberty.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on hypertrophy, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. The liver post hepatectomy

❌ Incorrect

This is an example of compensatory hyperplasia, not hypertrophy. Liver regenerates by cell proliferation, not cell enlargement. (Robbins, p. 32)

B. Tissue with a high capillary to myocyte ratio

❌ Incorrect

This describes well-vascularised tissue, not a hallmark of hypertrophy. Hypertrophy involves increase in cell size, not necessarily vascular changes.

C. The pregnant uterus

✅ Correct

Robbins: "The gravid uterus enlarges due to hormone-induced hypertrophy of smooth muscle cells." (p. 32) This is a classic example of true hypertrophy.

D. The breast at puberty

❌ Incorrect

This is due to hormonal hyperplasia — proliferation of glandular epithelium, not hypertrophy. (p. 32)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. The pregnant uterus

This is the classic physiologic example of hypertrophy, specifically of smooth muscle cells in the uterus during pregnancy.

271

Which of the following pathological process is associated with the irreversible phase of hypovolaemic shock?

A. Bacteraemic shock secondary to gut ischaemia.

B. Lactic acidosis.

C. Renin/angiotensin system activation.

D. Disseminated intravascular coagulation.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on the irreversible phase of hypovolemic shock:

 

Question: Which of the following pathological process is associated with the irreversible phase of hypovolemic shock?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Bacteraemic shock secondary to gut ischaemia

✅ Correct

Robbins: “In the irreversible stage of shock, intestinal ischemia can cause bacterial translocation, leading to bacteremia and endotoxic shock, compounding the circulatory collapse.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Lactic acidosis

❌ Occurs earlier

Lactic acidosis results from anaerobic glycolysis during the progressive (middle) stage of shock due to hypoperfusion and hypoxia—not specific to the irreversible phaseRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Renin/angiotensin system activation

❌ Occurs in early/compensated phase

Robbins: “Compensatory mechanisms include activation of the renin–angiotensin system, ADH release, and sympathetic output.” These occur in the early, compensatory phaseRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

❌ Occurs in progressive or terminal stages

DIC can be seen in progressive or irreversible stages, but bacteremia secondary to gut ischemia is more characteristic and direct in irreversible hypovolemic shockRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Bacteraemic shock secondary to gut ischaemia

This is a hallmark of the irreversible stage of hypovolemic shock, where severe tissue injury and ischemia lead to multi-organ failure and systemic infectionRobbins and Cotran Path….

272

AIDS defining illnesses include all except:

A. Invasive cervical cancer.

B. Meliodosis.

C. Norcardiosis.

D. Histoplasmosis.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on AIDS-defining illnesses, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition and CDC AIDS criteria:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Invasive cervical cancer

✅ Included

Invasive cervical carcinoma is officially recognized as an AIDS-defining illness by the CDC due to its strong association with immunosuppression and HPV persistence.

“Invasive cervical cancer is one of the AIDS-defining cancers.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Melioidosis

❌ Not included ✅ Correct Answer

Melioidosis is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei and is more common in diabetics or immunocompromised patients, but it is not classified as an AIDS-defining illness.

Not listed among AIDS-defining conditions in Robbins or CDC guidelines.

C. Nocardiosis

✅ Included

Nocardiosis is caused by Nocardia species and is considered an opportunistic infection seen in AIDS patients, especially with CNS or pulmonary involvement.

“Nocardiosis is seen in immunocompromised hosts, including those with AIDS.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Histoplasmosis

✅ Included

Disseminated histoplasmosis is a classic AIDS-defining opportunistic infection, especially in endemic regions (e.g., Mississippi/Ohio River valleys).

“Histoplasmosis, particularly when disseminated, is an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Melioidosis

Let me know if you'd like a full list of CDC-defined AIDS-defining illnesses in table form!

273

Regarding iron, which is false?

A. Absorption is increased by vitamin C.

B. Most is found in myoglobin.

C. Most in absorbed in duodenum.

D. Women have smaller iron stores than men.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on iron metabolism, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Absorption is increased by vitamin C

✅ True

Robbins: “Absorption of non-heme iron is enhanced by ascorbic acid (vitamin C), which reduces ferric (Fe³⁺) to ferrous (Fe²⁺) iron.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Most is found in myoglobin

❌ False

Robbins: “Approximately 80% of the functional iron is in hemoglobin. A smaller amount is in myoglobin and enzymes.” Thus, most iron is found in hemoglobin, not myoglobinRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Most is absorbed in the duodenum

✅ True

Robbins: “Dietary iron is absorbed primarily in the duodenum.” This is the main site for iron uptakeRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Women have smaller iron stores than men

✅ True

Robbins: “Women have smaller iron stores than men, which makes them more susceptible to iron deficiency anemia, especially during reproductive years.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: B. Most is found in myoglobin (This is false)

274

Chemical mediators of inflammation include all except:

A. C3a and C5a.

B. Bradykinin.

C. Histamine.

D. Protein C.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on chemical mediators of inflammation, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. C3a and C5a

✅ Correct

These are complement-derived mediators. C3a and C5a (anaphylatoxins) promote vascular permeability, chemotaxis, and leukocyte activation. (Robbins, p. 125)

B. Bradykinin

✅ Correct

Bradykinin is produced from kininogens and causes vasodilation, increased permeability, and pain — a classic inflammatory mediator. (p. 125)

C. Histamine

✅ Correct

Released by mast cells, basophils, and platelets, histamine causes vasodilation and increased vascular permeability — one of the earliest mediators of acute inflammation. (p. 124)

D. Protein C

❌ Incorrect (Correct answer)

Protein C is a natural anticoagulant that inhibits coagulation and promotes fibrinolysis. It is not a mediator of inflammation. (p. 314)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Protein C

Protein C is involved in coagulation regulation, not inflammatory mediation — making it the correct exception.

275

Acute pancreatitis:

A. May be caused by Helminth infection.

B. Causes hypercalcaemia.

C. Develop in 50% people with gallstones.

D. Leads to inhibition of elastase.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on acute pancreatitis:

 

Question: Acute pancreatitis:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. May be caused by Helminth infection.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Unusual infectious causes include Ascariasis and other helminthic infestations, especially in endemic areas, which may block the pancreatic duct and trigger pancreatitis.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Causes hypercalcaemia.

❌ Incorrect

Hypercalcemia is actually a cause of pancreatitis, not a result. Robbins: “Hypercalcemia (e.g., in hyperparathyroidism) is a recognized cause of acute pancreatitis.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Develops in 50% of people with gallstones.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Although gallstones are a major cause of pancreatitis, only a small minority of individuals with gallstones develop pancreatitis.” Far less than 50%Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Leads to inhibition of elastase.

❌ Incorrect

In fact, elastase is activated (along with trypsin and other enzymes), contributing to vascular damage and pancreatic necrosis in acute pancreatitisRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. May be caused by Helminth infection

Helminthic infestation, especially Ascaris lumbricoides, is a rare but recognized cause of acute pancreatitis due to duct obstructionRobbins and Cotran Path….

276

Chronic pancreatitis:

A. Has equal prevalence between the sexes.

B. Is predisposed to by hyperlipoproteinaemia.

C. Does not commence until adulthood.

D. Always has an identifiable precipitant.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on chronic pancreatitis, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Has equal prevalence between the sexes.

❌ Incorrect

Chronic pancreatitis is more common in males, particularly due to the strong association with alcohol abuse, which is more prevalent in men.

“Chronic pancreatitis is more common in middle-aged male alcoholics.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Is predisposed to by hyperlipoproteinaemia.

✅ Correct

Hyperlipidemia (especially hypertriglyceridemia) is a recognized risk factor for both acute and chronic pancreatitis. It can cause recurrent attacks that lead to chronic disease.

“Other causes of chronic pancreatitis include... hyperlipidemia and hypercalcemia.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Does not commence until adulthood.

❌ Incorrect

Chronic pancreatitis can begin in childhood, particularly in hereditary forms caused by PRSS1 or SPINK1 gene mutations.

“Hereditary pancreatitis can begin in childhood and often progresses to chronic pancreatitis.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Always has an identifiable precipitant.

❌ Incorrect

In many cases, no clear cause is found, and these are classified as idiopathic chronic pancreatitis.

“In some patients no cause can be identified (idiopathic pancreatitis).”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Is predisposed to by hyperlipoproteinaemia

Let me know if you'd like a comparison of acute vs chronic pancreatitis in table form!

277

Regarding pericarditis:

A. Constrictive pericarditis usually occurs after suppurative pericarditis.

B. Primary pericarditis is usually bacterial in origin.

C. Haemorrhagic pericarditis may be due to ureamia.

D. Haemorrhagic pericarditis is most commonly due to Klebsiella infection.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on pericarditis, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Constrictive pericarditis usually occurs after suppurative pericarditis

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Healed purulent or caseous pericarditis may result in dense fibrotic scars, producing constrictive pericarditis.” Suppurative (purulent) inflammation is a known precursor to this complicationRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Primary pericarditis is usually bacterial in origin

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Primary pericarditis is unusual and almost always of viral origin.” Bacteria more commonly cause secondary pericarditis, often via spread from adjacent infections or bloodstreamRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Haemorrhagic pericarditis may be due to uraemia

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Hemorrhagic pericarditis occurs in malignancy, tuberculosis, or following cardiac surgery, and occasionally in patients with severe uremia.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Haemorrhagic pericarditis is most commonly due to Klebsiella infection

❌ Incorrect

Klebsiella is not a typical cause. Robbins does not list Klebsiella among common causes. Malignancy, tuberculosis, and uremia are far more common etiologiesRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Haemorrhagic pericarditis is most commonly due to Klebsiella infection (This is false)

278

The following are true for cirrhosis except:

A. It is among the top 10 leading causes of death in the western world.

B. The pathogenic process is progressive fibrosis.

C. It may be clinically silent.

D. Alcoholic liver disease is the aetiology in 30% of cases in the Western world.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on cirrhosis, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. It is among the top 10 leading causes of death in the western world.

✅ Correct

Cirrhosis remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality, ranking among the top 10 causes of death in developed countries. (Robbins, p. 844)

B. The pathogenic process is progressive fibrosis.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "Cirrhosis is the end-stage of chronic liver disease, defined by diffuse fibrosis and the conversion of normal liver architecture into structurally abnormal nodules." (p. 844)

C. It may be clinically silent.

✅ Correct

Early-stage cirrhosis can be asymptomatic and often goes undetected until complications arise. (p. 844)

D. Alcoholic liver disease is the aetiology in 30% of cases in the Western world.

❌ Incorrect (Correct answer)

Alcoholic liver disease accounts for a larger proportion — closer to 60–70% of cirrhosis cases in some Western populations. Robbins states alcohol is the most common cause. The 30% figure underestimates its contribution. (p. 845)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Alcoholic liver disease is the aetiology in 30% of cases in the Western world

This statement is false because alcoholic liver disease accounts for a higher percentage of cirrhosis cases than stated.

279

Metaplasia is:

A. Reversible change from one cell type to another.

B. Irreversible change from one cell type to another.

C. Reduced function of cell.

D. Increase in the number of cells.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on metaplasia:

 

Question: Metaplasia is:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Reversible change from one cell type to another.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type better able to withstand the adverse environment.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Irreversible change from one cell type to another.

❌ Incorrect

Metaplasia is reversible if the injurious stimulus is removed; it is not a permanent transformationRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Reduced function of cell.

❌ Incorrect

Metaplasia refers to cell type transformation, not directly to loss of function (though the new cells may be less specialized for original function)Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Increase in the number of cells.

❌ Incorrect

An increase in cell number is termed hyperplasia, not metaplasiaRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Reversible change from one cell type to another

Metaplasia is an adaptive, reversible cellular response to stress or injury, where one differentiated cell type is replaced by another better suited to the environmentRobbins and Cotran Path….

280

The majority of global HIV/AIDS cases are reported from:

A. Homosexual males.

B. IVDU.

C. Haemophiliacs.

D. Heterosexual contact.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on global HIV/AIDS epidemiology, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Homosexual males

❌ Incorrect

While men who have sex with men (MSM) are a significant group in Western countries, this is not the dominant transmission mode globally.

“In the United States, male-to-male sexual contact accounts for the largest number of HIV cases, but globally, heterosexual transmission predominates.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. IVDU (Intravenous Drug Use)

❌ Incorrect

IVDU is a recognized risk group but accounts for a minority of global HIV infections.

“Intravenous drug use is a route of transmission but contributes less to the global burden than heterosexual spread.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Haemophiliacs

❌ Incorrect

Transmission through contaminated clotting factors occurred early in the epidemic but is now rare, and never contributed significantly to global case numbers.

“HIV infection in hemophiliacs was a serious problem early on, but current screening has virtually eliminated this route.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Heterosexual contact

✅ Correct

Heterosexual transmission accounts for the majority of global HIV cases, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, where the epidemic is most severe.

“Worldwide, the major route of HIV transmission is heterosexual contact.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Heterosexual contact

Let me know if you'd like a visual map or breakdown of HIV transmission by region!

281

A young man presents with central chest pain presumed to be associated with vasoconstriction. Most likely cause of pain is local:

A. Hypoxia.

B. Decreased ATP.

C. Increased CO2.

D. Catecholamines acting on alpha 1 receptors.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on chest pain due to vasoconstriction, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition and standard cardiovascular physiology:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Hypoxia

❌ Incorrect

While hypoxia is a consequence of vasoconstriction, it is not the direct cause of the vasoconstriction itself or pain in this context. It contributes to ischemia but is a downstream effect.

B. Decreased ATP

❌ Incorrect

Decreased ATP occurs during ischemia, but again, this is a result of reduced perfusion, not a cause of vasoconstriction.

C. Increased CO₂

❌ Incorrect

CO₂ is a vasodilator, not a vasoconstrictor. It promotes increased blood flow, especially in the brain and muscles, to flush out metabolic waste.

D. Catecholamines acting on alpha-1 receptors

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Vasoconstriction is mediated by sympathetic stimulation via α1-adrenergic receptors on vascular smooth muscle.” This can reduce coronary blood flow, causing transient ischemia and chest pain (e.g., in Prinzmetal/variant angina)Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Catecholamines acting on alpha-1 receptors

282

After occlusion of a coronary artery:

A. Loss of contractility occurs only when ultra structural changes in the myocyte are present.

B. The ischaemia is most pronounced in the epicardial region.

C. Reperfusion of the ischaemic area can result in new cellular damage, due to the generation of oxygen free radicals.

D. Q waves on an ECG are diagnostic of transmural infarction.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on myocardial infarction and coronary artery occlusion, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Loss of contractility occurs only when ultrastructural changes in the myocyte are present.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: "Loss of myocardial contractility can occur within 60 seconds of ischemia — before ultrastructural changes are visible." (p. 553)

B. The ischaemia is most pronounced in the epicardial region.

❌ Incorrect

Ischaemia is most pronounced in the subendocardial region, which is furthest from the coronary blood supply and most vulnerable. (p. 554)

C. Reperfusion of the ischaemic area can result in new cellular damage, due to the generation of oxygen free radicals.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "Reperfusion injury results from the generation of oxygen free radicals, calcium overload, and inflammatory responses." (p. 556)

D. Q waves on an ECG are diagnostic of transmural infarction.

❌ Incorrect
