While Q waves are suggestive of a transmural MI, they are not always present and are not diagnostic on their own. Diagnosis requires correlation with symptoms, enzymes, and ECG changes. (p. 556)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Reperfusion of the ischaemic area can result in new cellular damage, due to the generation of oxygen free radicals

This is a well-established mechanism known as reperfusion injury.

283

Which of the following statements regarding dilated cardiomyopathy is true?

A. Pregnancy is not a risk factor.

B. 5yr mortality rate is 50%.

C. End stage disease, patients have an ejection fraction <25%.

D. Most commonly affects adults between ages of 30-50.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM):

 

Question: Which of the following statements regarding dilated cardiomyopathy is true?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Pregnancy is not a risk factor.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a form of dilated cardiomyopathy that occurs in the late pregnancy or postpartum period. Pregnancy is a recognized risk factor.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. 5-year mortality rate is 50%.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The prognosis is poor. Only 25%–35% survive beyond 5 years, and fewer than 50% are alive at 2 years without transplantation.” So the 5-year mortality approaches 50% or worseRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. End-stage disease, patients have an ejection fraction <25%.

❌ Incorrect

While EF is reduced in DCM, Robbins defines it more broadly: “EF is typically less than 40%.” EF <25% may occur, but this value is not uniquely used to define end-stage disease in RobbinsRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Most commonly affects adults between ages of 30–50.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins notes that DCM “can occur at any age, including childhood,” though most commonly presents between ages 20–60 — so the age range in option D is too narrowRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. 5-year mortality rate is 50%

Dilated cardiomyopathy has a high mortality rate, with <50% 5-year survival without transplant, making this the correct Robbins-based answerRobbins and Cotran Path….

284

With regard to the WBC extravasation of the acute inflammatory response, which is false?

A. ELAM-1 is a selectin found on endothelium.

B. E and P-selectins bind to sialylated oligosaccharides found on neutrophils and monocytes.

C. L-selectin is found on leukocytes.

D. ICAM-1 belongs to the immunoglobulin family of molecules and is found on leukocytes.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on WBC (leukocyte) extravasation during acute inflammation, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. ELAM-1 is a selectin found on endothelium.

✅ True

ELAM-1 (now called E-selectin) is expressed on endothelial cells and plays a role in leukocyte rolling during inflammation.

“E-selectin (formerly ELAM-1) is expressed on activated endothelium and mediates rolling of leukocytes.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. E and P-selectins bind to sialylated oligosaccharides found on neutrophils and monocytes.

✅ True

E-selectin and P-selectin recognize sialyl-Lewis X-modified oligosaccharides on leukocytes, facilitating the rolling interaction.

“E- and P-selectins bind to sialylated oligosaccharides on leukocytes such as sialyl-Lewis X.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. L-selectin is found on leukocytes.

✅ True

L-selectin is expressed on neutrophils, monocytes, and naïve lymphocytes, where it helps initiate rolling by binding ligands on endothelial cells.

“L-selectin is expressed on leukocytes and binds to endothelial ligands.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. ICAM-1 belongs to the immunoglobulin family of molecules and is found on leukocytes.

❌ False ✅ Correct Answer

ICAM-1 is indeed part of the immunoglobulin superfamily, but it is expressed on endothelial cells, not on leukocytes. It binds to integrins (e.g., LFA-1) on leukocytes to mediate firm adhesion.

“ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 are members of the immunoglobulin family expressed on endothelial cells… they bind to integrins on leukocytes.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. ICAM-1 belongs to the immunoglobulin family of molecules and is found on leukocytes.

Let me know if you’d like a labeled diagram or table summarizing the steps and molecules involved in leukocyte extravasation!

285

A 38-year-old man has noticed increasing weakness and numbness in his legs and arms over the past three days and today he is feeling short of breath on exertion. Six weeks ago he had diarrhoea while on holiday to USA and stool culture-confirmed infection with Campylobacter jejuni. He was treated with azithromycin and recovered fully.What is the most likely diagnosis from the given list?

A. Motor neurone disease.

B. Myasthenia gravis.

C. Guillain-Barré syndrome.

D. Multiple sclerosis.

E. EEaton Lambert syndrome.

The most likely diagnosis is:

✅ C. Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

 

🔍 Explanation (with Robbins support):

This patient presents with:

  • Ascending weakness and numbness (legs → arms)
  • Shortness of breath on exertion (suggesting diaphragm or intercostal muscle involvement)
  • A history of Campylobacter jejuni infection 6 weeks prior

These are classic features of Guillain-Barré Syndrome, a post-infectious autoimmune demyelinating neuropathy.

 

📘 Robbins Reference:

“Guillain-Barré syndrome is an acute-onset immune-mediated demyelinating neuropathy. It is the most common cause of acute flaccid paralysis... In about two-thirds of cases, Guillain-Barré syndrome is preceded by an acute, influenza-like illness, and Campylobacter jejuni is a frequently identified trigger.”

—Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th ed.Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

❌ Why the others are incorrect:

Option

Why It's Incorrect

A. Motor neurone disease

Chronic, progressive; not acute onset over 3 days.

B. Myasthenia gravis

Presents with fluctuating weakness (esp. ocular muscles), not ascending paralysis or sensory symptoms.

D. Multiple sclerosis

Central demyelination; more often affects vision and shows CNS-specific signs, not peripheral ascending pattern.

E. Eaton-Lambert syndrome

Associated with paraneoplastic syndrome (e.g. small cell lung cancer); weakness improves with activity, not worse.

 

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Guillain-Barré Syndrome

286

Acute pancreatitis:

A. Is associated with increased serum amylase without a rise in serum lipase.

B. Occurs most often in later life.

C. Occurs in about 5% people with gallstones.

D. When associated with alcohol is not usually preceded by chronic pancreatitis.

You're absolutely right — let’s clarify this.

There are two different statistics at play:

 

✅ 1. Aetiology of Acute Pancreatitis (What Causes It):

Robbins (10th ed., p. 648) states:

"About 80% of cases of acute pancreatitis are due to either gallstones or alcohol abuse."

  • Gallstones = most common cause in women
  • Alcohol = most common cause in men

 

✅ 2. Risk of Acute Pancreatitis in People with Gallstones:

Also from Robbins:

"About 5% of individuals with gallstones develop acute pancreatitis."

 

🔍 So putting it together:

Statistic

Meaning

80%

Of all acute pancreatitis cases, ~80% are caused by gallstones or alcohol.

5%

Of all people with gallstones, about 5% will develop pancreatitis.

 

 

✅ Conclusion:

Both statements are correct but refer to different populations:

  • One is what proportion of pancreatitis cases are caused by gallstones/alcohol.
  • The other is how likely someone with gallstones is to develop pancreatitis.

Let me know if you want this shown in a diagram or chart.

287

Conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia results from:

A. Gilbert’s Syndrome.

B. Physiological jaundice.

C. Excess production of bilirubin.

D. Cholestasis.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on conjugated hyperbilirubinemia:

 

Question: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia results from:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Gilbert’s Syndrome

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Gilbert syndrome results from reduced activity of UDP-glucuronyltransferase, leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Physiological jaundice

❌ Incorrect

Seen in newborns, due to immature conjugating system; causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemiaRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Excess production of bilirubin

❌ Incorrect

Seen in hemolysis, this overwhelms conjugation capacity and results in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemiaRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Cholestasis

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia results when conjugated bilirubin cannot reach the intestine due to obstruction of bile flow — as in cholestasis.” This leads to regurgitation of conjugated bilirubin into the bloodRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Cholestasis

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is a hallmark of cholestatic conditions, due to impaired bile flow and reflux of conjugated (direct) bilirubin into the circulationRobbins and Cotran Path….

288

In acute inflammation, opsonisation is not enhanced by:

A. C3b.

B. Lectins.

C. Fc fragments of IgG.

D. C5b.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on opsonization in acute inflammation, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. C3b

✅ Enhances opsonization

C3b is a key opsonin produced during complement activation. It binds to microbial surfaces and enhances phagocytosis by binding complement receptors on leukocytes.

“The most important opsonins are antibodies (IgG), complement protein C3b, and certain lectins.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Lectins

✅ Enhance opsonization

Certain mannose-binding lectins (MBL) can act as opsonins by binding carbohydrates on microbial surfaces and enhancing phagocytosis.

“Mannose-binding lectin... acts as an opsonin by binding to microbial surfaces.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Fc fragments of IgG

✅ Enhance opsonization

The Fc region of IgG antibodies binds to Fc receptors on phagocytes, facilitating opsonization and ingestion of antibody-coated microbes.

“IgG antibodies bind antigens and interact with Fc receptors on phagocytes to promote opsonization.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. C5b

❌ Does NOT enhance opsonization ✅ Correct Answer

C5b is involved in the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC), not opsonization. It contributes to cell lysis, not enhanced phagocytosis.

“C5b initiates formation of the membrane attack complex… it does not function in opsonization.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. C5b

Let me know if you’d like a summary chart of complement proteins and their immune functions!

289

Which of the following is a common cause of fungal endocarditis?

A. Candida.

B. Cryptococcus.

C. Actinomyces.

D. Aspergillus.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on fungal endocarditis, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Candida

✅ Correct

Robbins states: “Fungal endocarditis is most commonly caused by Candida species and, less frequently, Aspergillus.” Candida is the most frequent fungal pathogen in both native and prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially in immunocompromised or IV drug usersRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Cryptococcus

❌ Incorrect

Cryptococcus is a fungal pathogen associated more commonly with meningitis, especially in AIDS, but rarely causes endocarditis.

C. Actinomyces

❌ Incorrect

Actinomyces is a gram-positive filamentous bacterium, not a fungus. It causes chronic suppurative infections, not typical fungal endocarditis.

D. Aspergillus

❌ Partially correct but not the most common

Aspergillus can cause endocarditis, but it is less common than Candida. Robbins lists Aspergillus as a less frequent fungal causeRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: A. Candida

290

Hepatitis B virus:

A. Is an unenveloped particle.

B. Is an RNA virus.

C. Is a member of the hepadnaviridae family.

D. Results in chronic hepatitis in 30% acute infections.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on Hepatitis B virus (HBV), based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Is an unenveloped particle.

❌ Incorrect

HBV is an enveloped virus. Robbins: "HBV is a partially double-stranded DNA virus with an outer lipid envelope containing HBsAg." (p. 839)

B. Is an RNA virus.

❌ Incorrect

HBV is a DNA virus, not RNA. It has a unique replication cycle involving reverse transcription, but the virus itself is DNA-based. (p. 839)

C. Is a member of the hepadnaviridae family.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "HBV belongs to the Hepadnaviridae family, a group of hepatotropic DNA viruses." (p. 839)

D. Results in chronic hepatitis in 30% acute infections.

❌ Incorrect

Chronic infection develops in <5% of adults, but in 90% of neonates. So 30% is an overestimate for most populations. (p. 839)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Is a member of the hepadnaviridae family

HBV is a partially double-stranded DNA virus in the Hepadnaviridae family, with a unique reverse transcription replication cycle.

291

Renin secretion is increased by:

A. High Na and Cl reabsorption across the macula densa.

B. Increased afferent arteriole pressure.

C. A decrease in sodium levels in the ultrafiltrate of the nephron

D. ADH.

Here is the Robbins-based and physiologically accurate evaluation of the question on renin secretion:

 

Question: Renin secretion is increased by:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins and physiology sources

A. High Na and Cl reabsorption across the macula densa

❌ Incorrect

High sodium and chloride delivery to the macula densa suppresses renin. Robbins/physiology: “Low NaCl at the macula densa stimulates renin release from juxtaglomerular cells.”

B. Increased afferent arteriole pressure

❌ Incorrect

Increased pressure inhibits renin. Renin secretion is stimulated by decreased perfusion pressure at the afferent arteriole (renal baroreceptor mechanism).

C. A decrease in sodium levels in the ultrafiltrate of the nephron

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Low sodium in the tubular fluid at the macula densa stimulates renin release,” part of the kidney’s mechanism to restore volume and pressureRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. ADH

❌ Incorrect

ADH (vasopressin) regulates water retention, not directly involved in renin secretion. Its effects are mostly independent of the RAAS system.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. A decrease in sodium levels in the ultrafiltrate of the nephron

Low Na⁺ sensed by the macula densa is a key stimulus for renin secretion, which activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) to restore blood pressure and volumeRobbins and Cotran Path….

292

Hypertrophy:

A. Occurs after partial hepatectomy.

B. Is triggered by mechanical and tropic chemicals.

C. Increases function of an organ exponentially.

D. Is usually pathological.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on hypertrophy, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Occurs after partial hepatectomy.

❌ Incorrect

After partial hepatectomy, the liver regenerates primarily via hyperplasia (increase in cell number), not hypertrophy.

“Liver regeneration after partial hepatectomy occurs mainly by hyperplasia of the remaining hepatocytes.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Is triggered by mechanical and tropic chemicals.

✅ Correct

Hypertrophy is stimulated by both mechanical triggers (e.g., stretch in cardiac muscle) and trophic signals (e.g., growth factors, hormones like IGF-1).

“Hypertrophy is caused by increased functional demand or by specific hormonal stimulation… mechanical and trophic triggers.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Increases function of an organ exponentially.

❌ Incorrect

Hypertrophy increases functional capacity of a tissue proportionally, not exponentially. The increase is often limited by structural or metabolic constraints.

Robbins describes increased functional demand but not exponential enhancement.

D. Is usually pathological.

❌ Incorrect

Hypertrophy can be physiological (e.g., in skeletal muscle from exercise or uterus in pregnancy) or pathological (e.g., in hypertension).

“Hypertrophy may be physiologic or pathologic, caused by increased functional demand or hormonal stimulation.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Is triggered by mechanical and tropic chemicals

Let me know if you'd like a comparison chart of hypertrophy vs hyperplasia vs atrophy vs metaplasia!

293

In compensated cardiac hypertrophy, which of the following changes occur?

A. Increased capillary density.

B. Decreased sarcomeres.

C. Hyperplasia.

D. Diffuse fibrosis.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on compensated cardiac hypertrophy, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Increased capillary density

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “The hypertrophied muscle has no proportional increase in capillary number, leading to relative ischemia.” Thus, capillary density does not increase, and oxygen supply may become inadequate as hypertrophy progressesRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Decreased sarcomeres

❌ Incorrect

Sarcomeres are increased, not decreased. Robbins: “Hypertrophy is characterized by an increase in the size of the cells, particularly through the addition of sarcomeres.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

C. Hyperplasia

❌ Incorrect

Cardiac muscle cells are terminally differentiated and do not undergo hyperplasia. Robbins: “In the heart, hypertrophy occurs without hyperplasia.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Diffuse fibrosis

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Myocardial hypertrophy is often associated with interstitial fibrosis, which can impair diastolic relaxation and contribute to heart failure.” While initially adaptive, this fibrosis becomes maladaptive over timeRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Diffuse fibrosis

294

Which of the following statement about chronic inflammation is true?

A. When resolved will allow return to normal tissue architecture.

B. Involves predominately neutrophil.

C. Is a feature of many autoimmune diseases.

D. Demonstrates histological features indistinguishable from acute inflammation.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on chronic inflammation, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. When resolved will allow return to normal tissue architecture.

❌ Incorrect

Chronic inflammation often leads to fibrosis, tissue destruction, or scarring. Resolution with restoration of normal tissue is more typical of acute inflammation. (p. 129)

B. Involves predominately neutrophil.

❌ Incorrect

Neutrophils dominate in acute inflammation. Chronic inflammation is characterised by mononuclear cells: macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. (p. 129)

C. Is a feature of many autoimmune diseases.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "Chronic inflammation may follow acute inflammation or begin insidiously, as in autoimmune diseases, viral infections, and prolonged exposure to toxic agents." (p. 129)

D. Demonstrates histological features indistinguishable from acute inflammation.

❌ Incorrect

Chronic and acute inflammation have distinct histologic features — e.g., mononuclear infiltrate and fibrosis in chronic vs neutrophils and oedema in acute. (p. 129–130)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Is a feature of many autoimmune diseases

Chronic inflammation is a hallmark of autoimmune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus.

295

Granulomatous inflammation can be induced by:

A. Syphilis.

B. Foreign body.

C. Cat-scratch disease.

D. All of the above.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on granulomatous inflammation:

 

Question: Granulomatous inflammation can be induced by:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Syphilis

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Tertiary syphilis is associated with gummatous inflammation, a type of granulomatous response.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Foreign body

✅ Correct

“Foreign body granulomas are formed in response to relatively inert materials (e.g., talc, sutures) and are part of the granulomatous inflammation spectrum.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Cat-scratch disease

✅ Correct

“Cat-scratch disease (caused by Bartonella henselae) produces stellate necrotizing granulomas in lymph nodes.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. All of the above

✅ Correct

Since each of the conditions listed is associated with granulomatous inflammation, this is the correct choice.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. All of the above

Granulomatous inflammation is a chronic inflammatory response triggered by persistent pathogens (e.g., Treponema pallidum, Bartonella), or foreign materials, as clearly outlined in RobbinsRobbins and Cotran Path….

296

All of the following are cardiac compensatory responses that occur in heart failure except:

A. Cardiac muscle fibre stretching.

B. Increased adrenergic receptors on cardiac cells.

C. Chamber hypertrophy.

D. Decreased heart rate.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on cardiac compensatory mechanisms in heart failure, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Cardiac muscle fibre stretching.

✅ True (Compensatory)

Stretching of cardiac muscle fibers increases contractile force (Frank-Starling mechanism), which is a compensatory response in early heart failure.

“Increased end-diastolic filling causes stretching of myocardial fibers… leading to more forceful contractions (Frank-Starling mechanism).”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Increased adrenergic receptors on cardiac cells.

✅ True (Compensatory)

Sympathetic activation increases heart rate and contractility. Initially, there’s upregulation or enhanced sensitivity of β-adrenergic receptors, although chronic overstimulation later leads to desensitization.

“Sympathetic stimulation increases heart rate, contractility, and peripheral vascular resistance in an attempt to maintain perfusion.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Chamber hypertrophy.

✅ True (Compensatory)

Cardiac hypertrophy is a well-known response to increased workload in heart failure. It helps maintain output but eventually becomes maladaptive.

“Hypertrophy of cardiac myocytes occurs in response to increased workload… a key compensatory mechanism.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Decreased heart rate.

❌ False ✅ Correct Answer

Heart failure causes increased sympathetic output, leading to tachycardia, not bradycardia. Decreased heart rate is not a compensatory response in heart failure.

“Heart failure activates the sympathetic nervous system, increasing heart rate and contractility.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Decreased heart rate

Let me know if you'd like a visual on the stages and compensations in heart failure!

297

Anaplasia is not characterized by :

A. Pleomorphism.

B. Abundant nuclear DNA.

C. A nuclear : cytoplasm of 1 : 6.

D. Coarsely clumped chromatin.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on anaplasia, with direct support from Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

📘 Robbins Definition of Anaplasia:

“Anaplasia refers to a lack of differentiation, a hallmark of malignant transformation.”

It is characterized by several morphologic features:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Pleomorphism

✅ True

Robbins: “Pleomorphism (variation in size and shape of cells and nuclei) is a characteristic feature of anaplastic cells.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Abundant nuclear DNA

✅ True

Robbins notes anaplastic cells often have hyperchromatic (deeply stained) nuclei, reflecting abundant and abnormal DNA contentRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. A nuclear : cytoplasm of 1 : 6

❌ False

This is the incorrect statement, and thus the correct answer to the MCQ. Anaplastic and malignant cells typically have a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, often 1:1 or 1:2, not 1:6. Robbins: “An increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, approaching 1:1, is typical.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Coarsely clumped chromatin

✅ True

Robbins: “Anaplastic nuclei often show coarsely clumped chromatin and prominent nucleoli.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: C. A nuclear : cytoplasm of 1 : 6 (This is not a feature of anaplasia)

298

Viruses kill host cells by all of the following except:

A. Inhibiting host cell DNA, RNA from protein synthesis.

B. Damaging the plasma membrane.

C. Lysing cells.

D. By producing toxins.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on how viruses kill host cells, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Inhibiting host cell DNA, RNA, or protein synthesis

✅ Correct

Viruses often shut down host macromolecular synthesis, redirecting machinery to viral replication. (Robbins, p. 358)

B. Damaging the plasma membrane

✅ Correct

Some viruses alter membrane integrity, causing cell lysis or immune-mediated destruction. (p. 358)

C. Lysing cells

✅ Correct

Many viruses cause cytolysis either directly or as a result of immune responses. (p. 358)

D. By producing toxins

❌ Incorrect (Correct Answer)

Viruses do not produce toxins. Unlike bacteria, viruses do not secrete toxins as a mechanism of injury. (p. 358)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. By producing toxins

Viruses do not produce toxins — this is a distinguishing feature from bacteria.

299

Regarding Malignant neoplasms which of the following statement is correct?

A. Are independent of hormonal influence.

B. Are always composed of homogenous cell lines.

C. Arise from differentiated cells by a process of anaplasia.

D. Typically are more rapidly growing than benign neoplasms.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on malignant neoplasms:

 

Question: Regarding malignant neoplasms, which of the following statement is correct?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Are independent of hormonal influence.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: Many malignant tumors retain hormone responsiveness. For example, breast and prostate cancers are often hormone-dependent, and treatment may involve hormone modulationRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Are always composed of homogenous cell lines.

❌ Incorrect

Malignant neoplasms often show cellular heterogeneity, including varying degrees of differentiation and genetic mutations within the tumor massRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Arise from differentiated cells by a process of anaplasia.

❌ Incorrect

Anaplasia refers to lack of differentiation, but Robbins emphasizes that malignant tumors arise from mutations affecting normal proliferative control, not simply by "dedifferentiation" of mature cellsRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Typically are more rapidly growing than benign neoplasms.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Malignant tumors tend to grow more rapidly than benign ones,” although growth rate may vary based on tumor type and differentiationRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Typically are more rapidly growing than benign neoplasms

Malignant neoplasms usually exhibit faster growth, invasive behavior, and metastatic potential, distinguishing them from benign tumorsRobbins and Cotran Path….

300

The most common cause of avascular necrosis of bones is:

A. Radiation therapy.

B. Caisson disease.

C. Vasculitis.

D. Steroid induced necrosis.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of bone, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Radiation therapy

❌ Incorrect

While radiation can damage vasculature and cause bone necrosis, it is a less common cause compared to steroids or trauma.

“Radiation may damage bone vasculature and lead to osteonecrosis, but it is not a frequent cause.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Caisson disease

❌ Incorrect

Caisson (decompression) disease can lead to avascular necrosis due to nitrogen emboli, but it is a rare cause overall.

“Caisson disease causes osteonecrosis due to nitrogen gas emboli, but this is rare.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Vasculitis

❌ Incorrect

Vasculitis can compromise blood flow and cause necrosis, but again, it is not the most common cause.

“Vasculitis involving bone vessels can lead to localized necrosis, but it is uncommon.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Steroid induced necrosis

✅ Correct

Corticosteroid use is the most common non-traumatic cause of avascular necrosis. It is strongly associated with osteonecrosis of the femoral head.

“The most common causes of osteonecrosis are fractures and corticosteroid administration.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Steroid induced necrosis

Let me know if you’d like a table summarizing causes, sites, and radiologic features of avascular necrosis!

301

Regarding metastasis whcih of the following statement is correct:

A. All carcinomas have the ability to metastasise.

B. Highly invasive carcinomas rarely metastasise.

C. Sarcomas typically spread via lymphatics compared with haematogenous spread.

D. Cells involved in lymphatic dissemination release degradative enzymes.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on metastasis, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. All carcinomas have the ability to metastasize

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Although most malignant tumors have the capacity to metastasize, not all do.” Some carcinomas (e.g. basal cell carcinoma) rarely metastasize despite being invasiveRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Highly invasive carcinomas rarely metastasize

❌ Incorrect

This is false — highly invasive carcinomas are more likely to metastasize. Robbins emphasizes that invasion is a prerequisite for metastasis, but not all invasive tumors necessarily spread.

C. Sarcomas typically spread via lymphatics compared with hematogenous spread

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Carcinomas tend to spread via lymphatics, whereas sarcomas spread hematogenously.” This statement reverses the actual patternRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Cells involved in lymphatic dissemination release degradative enzymes

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Tumor cell invasion requires degradation of the basement membrane and interstitial matrix. This is mediated by proteolytic enzymes such as matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs).” This applies to both lymphatic and hematogenous disseminationRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Cells involved in lymphatic dissemination release degradative enzymes

302

The commonest site of Berry aneurysm in the circle of Willis is:

A. Junction of anterior cerebral and anterior communicating artery.

B. Junction of middle cerebral and internal carotid.

C. Bifurcation of basilar artery.

D. The middle cerebral artery.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on Berry aneurysms (saccular aneurysms) of the circle of Willis, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Junction of anterior cerebral and anterior communicating artery

✅ Correct

This is the most common site of Berry aneurysms. Robbins: "Saccular (‘berry’) aneurysms most commonly occur at arterial branch points, particularly at the junction of the anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery." (p. 837)

B. Junction of middle cerebral and internal carotid

❌ Incorrect

This is a less common site. Aneurysms here can occur but are not the most frequent.

C. Bifurcation of basilar artery

❌ Incorrect

Aneurysms can occur here but are rare (~5% of cases).

D. The middle cerebral artery

❌ Incorrect

MCA bifurcation aneurysms occur, but the anterior communicating region is more common. MCA aneurysms rank second in frequency.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Junction of anterior cerebral and anterior communicating artery

This is the most common site for Berry aneurysms, and a major cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage when ruptured.

303

Staph aureus:

A. Has receptors on its surface that allow binding to host endothelial cells.

B. Has a capsule that allows it to attach to artificial materials.

C. Has a lipase that degrades lipids on the skin surface.

D. All of the above.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on Staphylococcus aureus:

 

Question: Staph aureus:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Has receptors on its surface that allow binding to host endothelial cells.

✅ Correct

Robbins: S. aureus expresses surface proteins (MSCRAMMs – microbial surface components recognizing adhesive matrix molecules) that bind to host matrix proteins like fibronectin and laminin, facilitating adherence to host tissues, including endotheliumRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Has a capsule that allows it to attach to artificial materials.

✅ Correct

Robbins notes: S. aureus can form biofilms and produce capsular polysaccharides that aid in adhesion to prosthetic devices and resist phagocytosisRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Has a lipase that degrades lipids on the skin surface.

✅ Correct

Robbins: S. aureus produces lipases, which degrade lipids in sebaceous secretions, helping colonization of the skinRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. All of the above

✅ Correct

Since all three statements are supported by Robbins, this is the best and correct choice.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. All of the above

S. aureus exhibits multiple virulence mechanisms, including adhesion to host tissues, capsule and biofilm formation, and lipase production for skin colonization — all contributing to its pathogenicityRobbins and Cotran Path….

304

Natural anticoagulants include:

A. vWF.

B. Protein C.

C. Protein P.

D. Antithrombin IV.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on natural anticoagulants, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. vWF (von Willebrand Factor)

❌ Incorrect

vWF is a pro-coagulant, not an anticoagulant. Robbins: “vWF serves as a bridge between platelets and exposed collagen and also binds factor VIII, protecting it from degradation.” It promotes platelet adhesion and stabilizes factor VIIIRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Protein C

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Protein C, activated by thrombomodulin-bound thrombin, inactivates factors Va and VIIIa, thus exerting an anticoagulant effect.” It is a key natural anticoagulantRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Protein P

❌ Incorrect

Protein P does not exist as a recognized factor in coagulation or anticoagulation. Likely a distractor or fictional choice.

D. Antithrombin IV

❌ Incorrect

Robbins and coagulation literature describe Antithrombin III (not IV) as a major anticoagulant: “Antithrombin III inhibits thrombin and other serine proteases involved in coagulation.” There is no Antithrombin IV described in standard sourcesRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: B. Protein C

305

Conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia:

A. Occurs when greater than 80% of bilirubin is conjugated.

B. Is a feature of Gilbert’s.

C. Is rarely associated with cholestasis.

D. Is often associated with a clinical picture of jaundice, pruritis and xanthomata.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Occurs when greater than 80% of bilirubin is conjugated.

✅ Correct

Conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia is defined when >50% to 80% of total serum bilirubin is in the conjugated (direct) form. (Robbins, p. 618)

B. Is a feature of Gilbert’s.

❌ Incorrect

Gilbert’s syndrome causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia due to reduced UDP-glucuronyltransferase activity. (p. 638)

C. Is rarely associated with cholestasis.

❌ Incorrect

Conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia is commonly associated with cholestasis, whether intrahepatic or extrahepatic. (p. 842)

D. Is often associated with a clinical picture of jaundice, pruritus and xanthomata.

✅ Correct

These are classic features of cholestatic jaundice, which involves conjugated bilirubin, bile salt retention (→ pruritus), and lipid accumulation (→ xanthomata). (p. 842)

 

 

✅ Correct Answers: A and D

Both A and D are correct, but if only one is allowed:

Best Single Correct Answer: D. Is often associated with a clinical picture of jaundice, pruritus and xanthomata

This reflects the clinical syndrome most commonly associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia.

306

Concerning Ca++ metabolism:

A. The net effect of PTH is to decrease serum PO4.

B. Vitamin D increases renal excretion of both Ca++ and PO4.

C. Calcitonin is secreted by parathyroid chief cells.

D. Insulin decreases bone formation.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on calcium (Ca²⁺) metabolism:

 

Question: Concerning Ca²⁺ metabolism:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. The net effect of PTH is to decrease serum PO₄.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases calcium levels by promoting bone resorption and renal calcium reabsorption, while increasing phosphate excretion in the urine, thus lowering serum phosphate levels.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Vitamin D increases renal excretion of both Ca²⁺ and PO₄.

❌ Incorrect

Vitamin D increases intestinal absorption of both calcium and phosphate, and does not promote their renal excretion — in fact, it helps retain themRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Calcitonin is secreted by parathyroid chief cells.

❌ Incorrect

Calcitonin is secreted by C-cells (parafollicular cells) of the thyroid gland, not the parathyroidRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Insulin decreases bone formation.

❌ Incorrect

Insulin is anabolic and generally promotes bone formation; there is no evidence in Robbins that it suppresses it. In fact, insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) support bone growthRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. The net effect of PTH is to decrease serum PO₄

This reflects PTH’s role in increasing calcium and lowering phosphate via enhanced renal phosphate excretionRobbins and Cotran Path….

307

Which of the following statements is correct regarding metastases ?

A. The breast usually metastasises to supraclavicular nodes.

B. They unequivocally prove malignancy.

C. They are the most common presentation of melanoma.

D. They are proven by the finding of lymph node enlargement adjacent to a tumour.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on metastases, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. The breast usually metastasises to supraclavicular nodes.

❌ Incorrect

Breast cancer typically first spreads to the axillary lymph nodes, not the supraclavicular nodes. The latter may be involved later as disease progresses.

“The most common site of lymphatic spread in breast cancer is to the axillary lymph nodes.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. They unequivocally prove malignancy.

✅ Correct

Metastasis is the most reliable hallmark of malignancy. Benign tumors do not metastasize, so their presence definitively indicates malignancy.

“Metastasis is the most reliable feature distinguishing malignant from benign tumors.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. They are the most common presentation of melanoma.

❌ Incorrect

Melanoma typically presents first as a primary pigmented skin lesion. Metastasis can occur later but is not the usual initial presentation.

“Melanomas usually begin as pigmented lesions in the skin; they may metastasize widely, but this is not their usual initial presentation.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. They are proven by the finding of lymph node enlargement adjacent to a tumour.

❌ Incorrect

Lymph node enlargement alone is not diagnostic of metastasis; it can result from reactive hyperplasia. Histologic confirmation of tumor cells in the node is required.

“Enlargement of lymph nodes near a tumor may result from immune response, not metastasis.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. They unequivocally prove malignancy

Let me know if you’d like a table of common primary cancers and their typical metastatic sites!

308

In compensated heart failure:

A. Right atrial pressure drops.

B. Renin level eventually drops below premorbid level.

C. Resting CO is unchanged.

D. Fluid retention plays no role.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on compensated heart failure, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Right atrial pressure drops

❌ Incorrect

In heart failure, right atrial pressure increases due to elevated venous return and impaired forward flow. Robbins: “Elevated filling pressures reflect impaired emptying of the heart chambers.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Renin level eventually drops below premorbid level

❌ Incorrect

Renin levels remain elevated due to decreased renal perfusion. Robbins: “Reduced perfusion of the kidneys leads to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), promoting sodium and water retention.” There is no evidence of eventual renin drop below normal in compensated failureRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Resting cardiac output is unchanged

✅ Correct

In compensated heart failure, resting cardiac output is preserved through mechanisms like ventricular hypertrophy, increased sympathetic tone, and fluid retention. Robbins: “In compensated heart failure, adaptive mechanisms maintain cardiac output at rest.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Fluid retention plays no role

❌ Incorrect

Fluid retention plays a central compensatory role by increasing preload to help maintain cardiac output (Frank-Starling mechanism). Robbins: “Retention of salt and water increases blood volume and venous return, augmenting cardiac output.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Resting cardiac output is unchanged

309

A patient with Von Willebrand’s disease may have what abnormality on FBC and/or clotting studies.

A. Increased PT.

B. Prolonged bleeding time.

C. Thrombocytopenia.

D. Mildly increased PT and APTT.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on von Willebrand disease (vWD), based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Increased PT

❌ Incorrect

Prothrombin time (PT) is typically normal in vWD, since the extrinsic pathway (measured by PT) is not affected. (Robbins, p. 310)

B. Prolonged bleeding time

✅ Correct

vWD leads to impaired platelet adhesion, resulting in a prolonged bleeding time, despite normal platelet count. (p. 310)

C. Thrombocytopenia

❌ Incorrect

Platelet count is usually normal in vWD; the defect is functional, not quantitative. (p. 310)

D. Mildly increased PT and APTT

❌ Incorrect

PT is normal; APTT may be prolonged due to decreased factor VIII stability, but PT is not typically affected. (p. 310)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Prolonged bleeding time

von Willebrand disease is characterised by a prolonged bleeding time and sometimes prolonged APTT, with a normal platelet count and PT.

310

In aseptic meningitis:

A. he glucose in the CSF is raised.

B. The most commonly identified agent is an enterovirus.

C. There is a more fulminant course than bacterial meningitis.

D. Microscopically there is a large infiltration of lymphocytes.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on aseptic meningitis:

 

Question: In aseptic meningitis:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. The glucose in the CSF is raised.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: In viral (aseptic) meningitis, “CSF glucose is usually normal,” not elevated. Elevated glucose is not a feature of any type of meningitisRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. The most commonly identified agent is an enterovirus.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The most common causes of aseptic meningitis are enteroviruses (especially echoviruses and coxsackieviruses).”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. There is a more fulminant course than bacterial meningitis.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Aseptic meningitis is typically self-limited and less fulminant than bacterial meningitis.” It has a better prognosisRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Microscopically there is a large infiltration of lymphocytes.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The inflammatory infiltrate in aseptic meningitis is predominantly lymphocytic, especially in the leptomeninges.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answers:

  • B. The most commonly identified agent is an enterovirus
  • D. Microscopically there is a large infiltration of lymphocytes

If the question is single-best-answer, then B is preferred as the key identifying feature.

If multiple options are allowed, both B and D are correct based on RobbinsRobbins and Cotran Path….

311

The hypothalamus is essential for:

A. Movement.

B. Visual acuity.

C. Renal function.

D. Speech.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on the functions of the hypothalamus, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition and neurophysiology:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Reference

A. Movement

❌ Incorrect

Movement is primarily controlled by the motor cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum, not the hypothalamus.

Robbins discusses motor control under cerebral cortex and basal ganglia.

B. Visual acuity

❌ Incorrect

Visual acuity is regulated by the retina, optic pathways, and visual cortex (occipital lobe). The hypothalamus is involved in circadian rhythms (via the suprachiasmatic nucleus), but not acuity.

Visual acuity is not a function of the hypothalamus.

C. Renal function

✅ Correct

The hypothalamus regulates renal function indirectly by controlling water balance through ADH secretion (via the posterior pituitary), thirst, and blood pressure regulation.

“The hypothalamus controls endocrine function… including water balance via ADH and thirst regulation.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Speech

❌ Incorrect

Speech production and comprehension are controlled by Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas in the cerebral cortex, not the hypothalamus.

Speech centers are localized in the cerebral cortex, not hypothalamus.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Renal function

The hypothalamus is critical for homeostatic functions, including thirst, fluid balance, temperature, hunger, and endocrine control via the pituitary.

Let me know if you'd like a table of hypothalamic nuclei and their specific functions!

312

Regarding malignant neoplasms:

A. Breast cancer is the commonest cause of death in females 55-74 year.

B. There is no familial clustering of ovarian cancer.

C. There is reasonable evidence available linking benzene with lung cancer.

D. Rates of lung cancer have doubled in the last 40 years.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on malignant neoplasms, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Breast cancer is the commonest cause of death in females 55–74 years

❌ Incorrect

While breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, the leading cause of cancer death in women (including ages 55–74) is lung cancer. Robbins: “Lung cancer remains the most common cause of cancer death in both men and women.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. There is no familial clustering of ovarian cancer

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “There is strong familial clustering of ovarian cancer. About 5% to 10% of ovarian cancers are familial, often due to BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations.”Robbins and Cotran Path…. So this statement is false.

C. There is reasonable evidence available linking benzene with lung cancer

❌ Incorrect

Benzene exposure is linked with leukemia, not lung cancer. Robbins: “Benzene is associated with an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), not lung cancer.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. Rates of lung cancer have doubled in the last 40 years

✅ Correct

Robbins: “The dramatic increase in lung cancer mortality over the past 50 years correlates closely with cigarette smoking.” Lung cancer rates increased significantly, especially in the mid-to-late 20th centuryRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Rates of lung cancer have doubled in the last 40 years

313

Regarding acute MI:

A. The majority of cases are uncomplicated.

B. Approximately 1/3 of complicated cases progress to cardiogenic shock.

C. 90% of complicated cases involve arrhythmia.

D. D>50% of complicated cases have further thromboembolic events in the recovery period.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on acute myocardial infarction (MI), based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. The majority of cases are uncomplicated.

❌ Incorrect

While some MIs are mild, most MIs have some degree of complication, including arrhythmias, heart failure, or pericarditis. Complications are common, even if not always fatal. (Robbins, p. 555–557)

B. Approximately 1/3 of complicated cases progress to cardiogenic shock.

✅ Correct

Robbins: "Cardiogenic shock occurs in ~10–15% of all MIs, but in ~1/3 of patients with severe LV dysfunction." This fits as ~1/3 of complicated cases. (p. 557)

C. 90% of complicated cases involve arrhythmia.

❌ Incorrect

While arrhythmias are the most common complication, affecting up to 80–90% of all MIs (not just complicated ones), the number specific to complicated cases is not clearly cited as 90%, making this overstated and misleading. (p. 556)

D. >50% of complicated cases have further thromboembolic events in the recovery period.

❌ Incorrect

Thromboembolic events can occur (e.g. mural thrombus → embolism), but >50% is an overestimate and not supported by Robbins. It is a known but less common complication. (p. 556)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Approximately 1/3 of complicated cases progress to cardiogenic shock

This is consistent with data from Robbins regarding cardiogenic shock in severe MIs.

314

Invasion by metastases includes:

A. Attachment of tumour cells to each others.

B. Attachment to matrix components.

C. Type I collagenases degrading extracellular matrix.

D. Absorption of proteolytic enzymes.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on invasion by metastases:

 

Question: Invasion by metastases includes:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Attachment of tumour cells to each other.

❌ Incorrect

Metastasis requires loss of intercellular adhesion. Robbins: “Tumor cells lose E-cadherin-mediated adhesion, reducing attachment to each other.” So detachment, not attachment, is requiredRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Attachment to matrix components.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Tumor cells adhere to components of the extracellular matrix (ECM) via receptors for laminin and fibronectin,” allowing invasion into stromaRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Type I collagenases degrading extracellular matrix.

❌ Incorrect

The correct enzymes are matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), particularly type IV collagenase, which degrade basement membrane. Type I collagenase is less specific here. Robbins emphasizes type IV collagen degradation in invasionRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Absorption of proteolytic enzymes.

❌ Incorrect

Tumor cells secrete (not absorb) proteolytic enzymes like MMPs, cathepsins, and others to break down ECM for invasionRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Attachment to matrix components

This is a critical early step in tumor invasion, allowing cells to interact with and migrate through the extracellular matrix via integrins and other receptorsRobbins and Cotran Path….

315

Staph aureus can cause all of the following except:

A. Food poisoning.

B. Osteomyelitis.

C. Carbuncles.

D. Scarlet fever.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on Staphylococcus aureus infections, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Food poisoning

✅ True

S. aureus causes rapid-onset food poisoning via ingestion of preformed enterotoxins. Symptoms occur within 1–6 hours.

“Staphylococcal food poisoning results from ingestion of preformed enterotoxin.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

B. Osteomyelitis

✅ True

S. aureus is the most common cause of hematogenous osteomyelitis, especially in children and IV drug users.

“S. aureus is the most frequent cause of hematogenous osteomyelitis.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Carbuncles

✅ True

Carbuncles are deep skin infections involving multiple hair follicles, and S. aureus is the most common cause.

“S. aureus causes furuncles and carbuncles through infection of hair follicles.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. Scarlet fever

❌ False ✅ Correct Answer

Scarlet fever is caused by Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) producing erythrogenic exotoxins, not Staphylococcus aureus.

“Scarlet fever is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes producing erythrogenic toxin.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Scarlet fever

Let me know if you'd like a table comparing S. aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes infections!

316

All of the following increase BSL except:

A. Adrenaline.

B. Cortisol.

C. Growth hormone.

D. LH (Luteinizing hormone).

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on hormones affecting blood sugar level (BSL), supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition and standard endocrine physiology:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Adrenaline

✅ Increases BSL

Epinephrine (adrenaline) promotes glycogenolysis and lipolysis, raising blood glucose. Robbins: “Catecholamines stimulate glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, elevating plasma glucose.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Cortisol

✅ Increases BSL

Cortisol is a glucocorticoid that promotes gluconeogenesis, reduces glucose uptake, and is diabetogenic. Robbins: “Glucocorticoids enhance gluconeogenesis and inhibit peripheral glucose uptake.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

C. Growth hormone

✅ Increases BSL

GH has anti-insulin effects—promoting lipolysis and decreasing glucose uptake. Robbins: “GH antagonizes insulin action and contributes to hyperglycemia.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

D. LH (Luteinizing hormone)

❌ Does not increase BSL

LH is involved in reproductive hormone regulation, not glucose metabolism. It does not affect BSL directly.

 

 

✅ Final Answer: D. LH (Luteinizing hormone) (Does not increase blood sugar)

317

Regarding the Clostridium species:

A. Wound infections caused by C.perfringens generally occur 7-10 days following surgery.

B. C.tetani produces an endotoxin which causes muscle spasm.

C. The toxin of C.botulinum blocks serotonin and dopamine receptors.

D. All are spore producing.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on Clostridium species, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition) and standard microbiological principles:

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Wound infections caused by C. perfringens generally occur 7–10 days following surgery.

❌ Incorrect

Clostridium perfringens causes gas gangrene, which typically presents within 1–3 days after injury or surgery — not 7–10 days. (Robbins, p. 362)

B. C. tetani produces an endotoxin which causes muscle spasm.

❌ Incorrect

C. tetani produces an exotoxin called tetanospasmin, a neurotoxin, not an endotoxin. It blocks inhibitory neurotransmitter release (GABA, glycine), leading to muscle spasms. (p. 362)

C. The toxin of C. botulinum blocks serotonin and dopamine receptors.

❌ Incorrect

C. botulinum produces botulinum toxin, which inhibits acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions, not serotonin or dopamine receptors. This leads to flaccid paralysis. (p. 362)

D. All are spore producing.

✅ Correct

All Clostridium species are anaerobic, Gram-positive, spore-forming bacilli. Spore formation is a key survival mechanism for these organisms. (p. 362)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. All are spore producing

This is the only accurate statement among the options and reflects a defining feature of Clostridium species.

318

A 68-year-old woman has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Over the past 3 days, she has become febrile, with a productive cough, and severe dyspnea. Auscultation of her chest reveals rales and expiratory wheezes. Laboratory studies show peripheral blood neutrophilia. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be cultured from her sputum?

A. Influenza A.

B. Moraxella Catarrhalis.

C. Mycobacterium Kansasii.

D. Pneumocystis Jiroveci.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on respiratory infection in a chronic smoker:

 

Clinical Summary:

  • 68-year-old chronic smoker (pack a day × 35 years → high risk for COPD)
  • Presents with fever, productive cough, dyspnea, rales, wheeze
  • Neutrophilia → suggests bacterial infection

 

Question: Which of the following organisms is most likely to be cultured from her sputum?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Influenza A

❌ Incorrect

Influenza A is viral, often causes non-productive cough, lymphocytosis, and may predispose to secondary bacterial pneumonia, but not the most likely cause of neutrophilic bronchopneumonia in a smokerRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Moraxella catarrhalis

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Moraxella catarrhalis is increasingly recognized as a cause of bacterial exacerbations of COPD.” It's a gram-negative diplococcus frequently isolated in older patients with chronic lung diseaseRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Mycobacterium kansasii

❌ Incorrect

This is a non-tuberculous mycobacterium, seen in immunocompromised or structural lung disease, but it causes a chronic, not acute, illness. No neutrophilia typically seenRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Pneumocystis jiroveci

❌ Incorrect

Pneumocystis jiroveci causes interstitial pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts (e.g., HIV), and is not neutrophil-predominant. This patient has no immunodeficiency historyRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Moraxella catarrhalis

This organism is a common cause of acute exacerbations of COPD in elderly smokers, especially with neutrophilic inflammation and bronchopneumoniaRobbins and Cotran Path….

319

A 25-year-old man incurs blunt chest trauma in a car accident. On examination, he has marked left chest wall pain. A chest radiograph shows a fractured 7th rib on the left side. Over the next 2 days, he has subcutaneous soft tissue swelling with nonpainful crepitance on palpation of the right chest wall. Leakage of which of the following is most likely producing this swelling?

A. Acid.

B. Air.

C. Blood.

D. Lymph.

Here is the analysis of this MCQ on post-traumatic chest injury and subcutaneous swelling, based on clinical pathology principles from Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Reference

A. Acid

❌ Incorrect

Acid leakage is not a typical consequence of blunt trauma to the chest or rib fractures. Acid would cause chemical burns, not crepitus or swelling.

Not relevant in trauma unless involving gastric perforation, which is not indicated here.

B. Air

✅ Correct

Crepitance with soft tissue swelling that is nonpainful and occurs after rib fracture is classic for subcutaneous emphysema, caused by air escaping from a damaged lung or airway and entering the subcutaneous tissue.

“Air in subcutaneous tissues (subcutaneous emphysema) may follow chest trauma or pneumothorax, producing crepitus on palpation.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Blood

❌ Incorrect

Blood in soft tissues causes hematoma, which is painful, firm, and does not produce crepitance.

Hemorrhage leads to swelling but not the characteristic crackling feel.

D. Lymph

❌ Incorrect

Lymphatic leakage (chylothorax or lymphocele) is uncommon in blunt chest trauma, and does not cause crepitus.

Lymph leakage is typically fluid accumulation, not air-related.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Air

Subcutaneous emphysema is a hallmark of air tracking into the soft tissues, often from trauma-induced pneumothorax or bronchial rupture. Let me know if you'd like a quick table on trauma-related chest pathologies!

320

The most common site of origin of emboli causing cerebrovascular disease is:

A. Common carotid.

B. Internal carotid.

C. Heart.

D. Either end of basilar artery.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on emboli causing cerebrovascular disease, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Common carotid

❌ Incorrect

While carotid artery atherosclerosis is important, the common carotid is not the most common site for embolic origin.

B. Internal carotid

❌ Incorrect

The internal carotid artery can be a source of atherosclerotic plaque emboli, but not the most common overall source of emboli in cerebrovascular disease.

C. Heart

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Embolism is the most common cause of cerebral infarction. In most cases, the emboli originate from a mural thrombus in the heart...” This includes emboli from atrial fibrillation, myocardial infarction, or valvular diseaseRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Either end of basilar artery

❌ Incorrect

Basilar artery involvement is more relevant in brainstem strokes, and it is not a common origin site for emboli. It may be an area affected by emboli, but not typically where they arise.

 

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Heart

321

The effects of thyroid hormone include all of the following except :

A. Increased activity of Na/K ATPase.

B. Increased nitrogen excretion.

C. Increased levels of catecholamines.

D. Increased carbohydrate absorption from the gut.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on the effects of thyroid hormone, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition) and standard endocrine physiology:

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Increased activity of Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase

✅ Correct

Thyroid hormone upregulates Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase, increasing basal metabolic rate and heat production. (Robbins, p. 1100)

B. Increased nitrogen excretion

✅ Correct

Thyroid hormone promotes protein catabolism, leading to increased nitrogen excretion (e.g. urea). Seen especially in hyperthyroidism.

C. Increased levels of catecholamines

❌ Incorrect (Correct answer)

Thyroid hormone does not increase catecholamine levels, but it increases tissue sensitivity to catecholamines by upregulating β-adrenergic receptors. (p. 1101)

D. Increased carbohydrate absorption from the gut

✅ Correct

Thyroid hormone enhances glucose absorption and utilization by increasing expression of carbohydrate transporters and digestive enzymes. (Robbins, p. 1100)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Increased levels of catecholamines

Thyroid hormone sensitizes tissues to catecholamines but does not increase their production or circulating levels.

322

Features of iron deficiency:

A. Increased serum ferritin.

B. Decreased transferring saturation.

C. Decreased TIBC.

D. hypochromic and macrocytic red cell

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on features of iron deficiency:

 

Question: Features of iron deficiency:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Increased serum ferritin

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Serum ferritin is reduced in iron deficiency.” It reflects body iron stores, so it decreases early in deficiencyRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Decreased transferrin saturation

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Transferrin saturation is decreased, reflecting less iron bound to transferrin despite increased TIBC.” It’s a key diagnostic marker of iron deficiency anemiaRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Decreased TIBC

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “In iron deficiency, there is a compensatory increase in total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) due to increased transferrin production.” So TIBC is increased, not decreasedRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Hypochromic and macrocytic red cell

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Iron deficiency results in hypochromic, microcytic anemia,” not macrocytic. Macrocytosis is typical of B12 or folate deficiencyRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Decreased transferrin saturation

This is a hallmark laboratory feature of iron deficiency anemia, along with low serum ferritin and high TIBC, and hypochromic microcytic red cellsRobbins and Cotran Path….

323

Following a needlestick from an HIV + patient the risk of HIV seroconversion is:

A. 1 in 5.

B. 1 in 10.

C. 1 in 50

D. 1 in 250

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on HIV seroconversion risk after a needlestick injury, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition and CDC epidemiologic data:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins / CDC Reference

A. 1 in 5

❌ Incorrect

This is far too high. A 20% seroconversion rate does not reflect the actual occupational transmission risk.

 

B. 1 in 10

❌ Incorrect

Still too high. Such a high rate would be expected with mucosal or blood transfusion exposure, not needlestick.

 

C. 1 in 50

✅ Correct

The risk of HIV seroconversion from a needlestick involving HIV-positive blood is ~0.3%, or 1 in 300, sometimes approximated as 1 in 50–100 depending on the viral load and nature of the injury.

“The risk of HIV transmission after percutaneous exposure is approximately 0.3%.”Robbins and Cotran Path… CDC also cites: “Estimated risk is 0.23% per needlestick exposure.”

D. 1 in 250

❌ Incorrect

While this is closer, the actual risk is slightly higher, making 1 in 50 the better approximation of typical teaching values.

 

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. 1 in 50

Let me know if you'd like a table of seroconversion risks for HIV, HBV, and HCV exposures!

324

Removal of sutures from a wound at 7 days coincides with a wound strength of:

A. 1% of unwounded skin strength.

B. 10% of unwounded skin strength.

C. 50% of unwounded skin strength.

D. 75% of unwounded skin strength.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on wound healing strength, with direct reference from Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. 1% of unwounded skin strength

❌ Incorrect

Wound strength increases more than 1% by day 7.

B. 10% of unwounded skin strength

✅ Correct

Robbins states:

 

“By the end of the first week, wound strength is approximately 10% of the strength of unwounded skin.”

This corresponds to the typical timing of suture removalRobbins and Cotran Path…. |

| C. 50% of unwounded skin strength | ❌ Incorrect | Wound strength reaches ~50% by 4–6 weeks, not 7 days. |

| D. 75% of unwounded skin strength | ❌ Incorrect | Robbins: “Wound strength plateaus at about 70% to 80% of normal by 3 months.” This is far beyond the 7-day markRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

✅ Final Answer: B. 10% of unwounded skin strength

325

With reference to wound healing:

A. Wound regain 70-80% normal strength by 3/12 (which may persist for life).

B. Zinc is essential for the synthesis of collagen.

C. Granulation tissue represents overproduction of collagen.

D. Intercurrent glucocorticoid therapy may assist in the reparative process.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on wound healing, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Wound regains 70–80% normal strength by 3/12 (which may persist for life).

✅ Correct

Robbins: "By 3 months, the wound typically regains about 70%–80% of the tensile strength of normal skin, and this may persist indefinitely." (p. 108)

B. Zinc is essential for the synthesis of collagen.

✅ Correct

Zinc is a cofactor for matrix metalloproteinases and enzymes like collagenase and lysyl oxidase, which are involved in collagen synthesis and cross-linking. (p. 106)

C. Granulation tissue represents overproduction of collagen.

❌ Incorrect

Granulation tissue is rich in new capillaries, fibroblasts, and loose ECM. It is not defined by excess collagen — that occurs later in fibrosis or keloid formation. (p. 106–107)

D. Intercurrent glucocorticoid therapy may assist in the reparative process.

❌ Incorrect

Glucocorticoids impair wound healing by inhibiting inflammation, collagen synthesis, and fibroblast proliferation. (p. 107)

 

 

✅ Correct Answers: A and B

If only one allowed:

Best Single Correct Answer: A. Wound regains 70–80% normal strength by 3/12 (which may persist for life)

This is the most specific and commonly tested fact in wound healing.

326

Malignant tumours:

A. When arising from epithelial cells are called sarcomas.

B. Are well differentiated.

C. When arising from glandular cells are called adenocarcinoma.

D. Rarely metastasise.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on malignant tumors, with direct support from Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. When arising from epithelial cells are called sarcomas

❌ Incorrect

Sarcomas arise from mesenchymal (connective tissue) cells. Robbins: “Malignant tumors of mesenchymal origin are called sarcomas, whereas those arising from epithelial cells are called carcinomas.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

B. Are well differentiated

❌ Incorrect

Malignant tumors may be well, moderately, poorly, or undifferentiated (anaplastic). Robbins: “Lack of differentiation (anaplasia) is a hallmark of malignancy.” Well-differentiation does not exclude malignancy but is less typical.

C. When arising from glandular cells are called adenocarcinoma

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Adenocarcinomas are malignant epithelial tumors with glandular growth patterns.” This is standard nomenclature for malignant tumors of glandular epitheliumRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Rarely metastasize

❌ Incorrect

Metastasis is a hallmark of malignancy. Robbins: “The ability to invade and metastasize strongly distinguishes malignant from benign tumors.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Final Answer: C. When arising from glandular cells are called adenocarcinoma

327

Which of the following intracellular proteins is most important in facilitating movement of endothelial cells?

A. Actin.

B. Cytokeratin.

C. Lamin.

D. Myosin.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on intracellular proteins involved in cell movement, particularly endothelial cell migration during processes like wound healing and angiogenesis, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition) and standard cell biology:

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Actin

✅ Correct

Actin filaments are essential for cell motility, especially in endothelial cell migration during wound healing and angiogenesis. Actin forms dynamic structures like lamellipodia and filopodia. (Robbins, p. 106)

B. Cytokeratin

❌ Incorrect

Cytokeratins are intermediate filaments found in epithelial cells, providing structural integrity — not involved in cell migration.

C. Lamin

❌ Incorrect

Lamins are intermediate filaments that form the nuclear lamina, supporting nuclear structure, not cytoplasmic movement.

D. Myosin

❌ Incorrect

Myosin interacts with actin in muscle contraction, but cell migration in non-muscle cells (like endothelial cells) depends more on actin polymerization than myosin.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Actin

Actin is the key intracellular protein facilitating endothelial cell movement during tissue repair and angiogenesis.

328

A 4-year-old boy has had a cough, headache, and slight fever for 5 days. He is now having increasing respiratory difficulty. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.8° C, the pulse is 81/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. On auscultation, there are inspiratory crackles, but no dullness to percussion or tympany. The respiratory syncytial virus is isolated on quick testing in the ED. Which of the following chest radiographic patterns is most likely to be present?

A. Hilar lymphadenopathy.

B. Hyperinflation.

C. Interstitial infiltrates.

D. Lobar consolidation.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question involving respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection in a young child:

 

Clinical Clues:

  • 4-year-old child with RSV infection
  • Mild fever, increasing respiratory difficulty
  • Inspiratory crackles, no lobar dullness
  • RSV = common viral cause of bronchiolitis/pneumonia in children

 

Question: Which of the following chest radiographic patterns is most likely to be present?

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Hilar lymphadenopathy

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: Hilar lymphadenopathy is more typical of tuberculosis, lymphoma, or fungal infections, not viral bronchiolitis like RSVRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Hyperinflation

✅ Correct

Robbins: RSV causes bronchiolitis with air trapping, leading to hyperinflated lungs on imaging. This is the classic finding in young children with RSVRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. Interstitial infiltrates

❌ Partially correct but less specific

While interstitial infiltrates can be seen in viral infections, hyperinflation is more characteristic and specific for RSV bronchiolitisRobbins and Cotran Path….

D. Lobar consolidation

❌ Incorrect

Lobar consolidation is a hallmark of bacterial pneumonia, especially due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, not typical of RSVRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Hyperinflation

RSV infection in young children typically produces bronchiolitis, which leads to air trapping and hyperinflated lungs on chest X-ray — a classic radiographic featureRobbins and Cotran Path….

329

With regard to blood types:

A. Group A is most common.

B. Anti A and anti B agglutinins increase into the 6th decade.

C. There are 6 possible ABO genotypes.

D. Group AB persons have both anti A and anti B agglutinins.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on blood types, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Group A is most common

❌ Incorrect

The most common blood group varies by population, but group O is the most common globally. Robbins mentions population differences, with group O often being predominantRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Anti-A and anti-B agglutinins increase into the 6th decade

❌ Incorrect

Naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B antibodies develop early in life (by 6 months) and do not progressively increase with age. Robbins: “Anti-A and anti-B antibodies appear within the first few months of life.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

C. There are 6 possible ABO genotypes

✅ Correct

The ABO system has three alleles: A, B, and O. The six possible genotypes are:

 

  • AA
  • AO
  • BB
  • BO
  • AB
  • OO
    Robbins supports this standard Mendelian genetic explanationRobbins and Cotran Path…. |
    |     D. Group AB persons have both anti-A and anti-B agglutinins | ❌ Incorrect | Group **AB individuals have no anti-A or anti-B antibodies. Robbins: “AB individuals can receive blood from all groups because they lack anti-A and anti-B antibodies.”Robbins and Cotran Path….

 

✅ Final Answer: C. There are 6 possible ABO genotypes

330

Pathogenesis of type I diabetes is associated with:

A. Decreased insulin sensitivity.

B. Abnormal glukokinase activity.

C. No antibodies found on diagnosis.

D. Auto immune insulitis.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on the pathogenesis of type I diabetes mellitus, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease (10th edition):

 

Answer Table:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Decreased insulin sensitivity

❌ Incorrect

Decreased insulin sensitivity (insulin resistance) is a hallmark of type II diabetes, not type I. (Robbins, p. 1127)

B. Abnormal glucokinase activity

❌ Incorrect

Mutations in glucokinase are associated with MODY (maturity-onset diabetes of the young), not classic type I diabetes.

C. No antibodies found on diagnosis

❌ Incorrect

In type I diabetes, islet autoantibodies (e.g., anti-GAD, anti-insulin) are often detectable even before clinical onset. (p. 1127)

D. Autoimmune insulitis

✅ Correct

Robbins: "Type I diabetes is characterized by autoimmune destruction of beta cells, often associated with insulitis—a lymphocytic infiltrate targeting islets." (p. 1127)

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Autoimmune insulitis

This reflects the central pathogenic mechanism in type I diabetes mellitus: immune-mediated destruction of pancreatic β-cells.

331

In MI the microvascular changes start

A. Immediately.

B. In 10-20 minutes.

C. In more than 1 hour.

D. In 6-12 hours.

Here is the Robbins-based evaluation of the question on microvascular changes in myocardial infarction (MI):

 

Question: In MI, the microvascular changes start:

Option

Evaluation

Explanation from Robbins

A. Immediately.

❌ Incorrect

While ischemia begins immediately, microvascular injury (damage to small blood vessels) does not start right away. Early changes are functional, not structuralRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. In 10–20 minutes.

❌ Incorrect

Robbins states that irreversible injury to myocytes begins in this time frame, but microvascular injury starts laterRobbins and Cotran Path….

C. In more than 1 hour.

✅ Correct

Robbins: “Microvascular injury (hemorrhage and endothelial swelling) begins after approximately 1 hour of ischemia and becomes irreversible after 1.5 to 2 hours.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

D. In 6–12 hours.

❌ Incorrect

By this time, necrosis is well established, and the inflammatory response begins. Microvascular damage starts earlier, around the 1-hour markRobbins and Cotran Path….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. In more than 1 hour

Microvascular injury in MI begins after >1 hour of ischemia, leading to hemorrhage and endothelial damage, and becomes irreversible by 1.5–2 hoursRobbins and Cotran Path….

332

Which virus causes molluscum contagiosum?

A. Adenovirus.

B. Herpes virus.

C. Parvovirus.

D. Pox virus.

Here is the analysis of the MCQ on molluscum contagiosum, based on Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

Option

Answer

Explanation

Robbins Reference

A. Adenovirus

❌ Incorrect

Adenoviruses cause conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, and respiratory infections, not molluscum contagiosum.

Adenovirus is not associated with skin lesions like molluscum.

B. Herpes virus

❌ Incorrect

Herpesviruses (e.g., HSV, VZV) cause vesicular lesions, not the umbilicated papules characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

“Herpes simplex viruses cause vesicles… not the dome-shaped papules of molluscum contagiosum.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

C. Parvovirus

❌ Incorrect

Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) in children, not molluscum contagiosum.

Parvovirus causes rash illness but not molluscum.

D. Pox virus

✅ Correct

Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus, specifically the molluscum contagiosum virus, a DNA virus in the Poxviridae family.

“Molluscum contagiosum is a common skin infection caused by a poxvirus.”Robbins and Cotran Path…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Pox virus

Let me know if you'd like a table comparing viral skin infections by causative agents and clinical features!

333

Oesophageal varices:

A. Occur in 1/3 of all cirrhotic patients.

B. Account for more than 50% of episodes of haematemesis.

C. Are most often associated with Hep C cirrhosis.

D. Have a 40% mortality during the first episode of rupture.

Here is the detailed analysis of the MCQ on esophageal varices, supported by Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition:

 

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Occur in 1/3 of all cirrhotic patients

❌ Incorrect

Robbins: “Varices are present in about 65% of patients with advanced cirrhosis.” So this is an underestimate — it’s closer to two-thirds, not one-thirdRobbins and Cotran Path….

B. Account for more than 50% of episodes of haematemesis

❌ Incorrect
